PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated one year from October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System and though the media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radio- active substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to Irradiate Food In Australia
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia
and
2. Ban the import of Cobalt 60 and Caesium 137 and Caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Arms
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that in the International Year of Peace, young Australians face an uncertain future due to:
1. a continuing arms race between the super-powers which threatens to extend into outer space
2. military expenditure continuing at ridiculously high levels
3. continuing testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons
Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to do everything possible to make our future more certain, by:
1. encouraging peaceful dialogue through diplomatic channels as the means of solving issues.
2. persuading all developed countries to spend less on armaments, and more on basic needs like food, health, shelter and education for all people of the world.
3. promoting the extension of agreements to reduce testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned concerned Australians, hereby petition the Honourable Senators to totally reject the current proposals for an I.D. Card and the proposed Data Protection Agency.

We believe that they represent potentially undesirable interference in the lives of honest Australians. Provision for protection of privacy cannot be guaranteed as Statutes are easily altered by future Governments.

We believe that there are more efficient methods to prevent fraud in the areas of Social Security and Taxation without the use of these two proposals, which go well beyond the reach of the true role of democratic government. i.e. That citizens may live quiet and peaceable lives.
The I.D. Card and the Data Protection Agency have strong potential under this or future administrations to interfere with the quiet and peaceable lives of its subjects.
We your humble petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the proposed Australia Card legislation is an infringement of privacy.
2. That the bureaucracy created by the introduction of the Australia Card will be a further burden to Australian Taxpayers-one that they can ill-afford in the present economic climate.
3. That the Australian Card will not tackle the problems of tax evasion, welfare fraud and illegal immigration successfully.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Continue to reject the Australia Card Bill preventing a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of privacy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland State Elections
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Honourable members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland showeth that the electoral system in Queensland, based on a 4 zonal weighted system, is an affront to democracy. The National Party under the leadership of Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen is always returned to Government with no opportunity for the voting public to bring about change.

Your petitioners point out that under the Queensland voting system the National Party at the State Elections on 1 November 1986 managed to achieve 55 per cent of the seats with only 39 per cent of the votes. This demonstrates that 61 per cent of Queenslanders do not want a National Party Government yet received one.

Your petitioners therefore earnestly pray that the Federal government legislates as a matter of urgency to bring about a democratic system of voting in Queensland State elections based on the principle of one vote one value.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) Australians are offended by taxation evasion and welfare fraud which has the effect of increasing the taxation burden of honest Australians.
(2) The community has shown its overwhelming support for the Government's decision to proceed with a national identification system known as the Australian Card.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable Senate will: continue the fight against taxation evasion and welfare fraud and restore fairness and equity to the tax and welfare systems by supporting the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Government's proposed Identity Card is the greatest threat to civil liberties in the history of this country;
(2) That the I.D. card will be a costly and unnecessary method of attacking tax evasion and social security fraud; and
(3) That the proposal will impose yet another bureaucratic burden on the business sector.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate reject the Government's legislation to introduce the Australia Card or any other identity card system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and senators in Parliament Assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and that the presence of nuclear-armed warships makes a priority nuclear target of ports being visited; and that the safety precautions for handling and deployment of nuclear weapons are inadequate to guarantee safety from accidents;

We therefore call upon the Australian Government to: prohibit the entry of nuclear weapons to Australia; and to deny access to Australian ports of foreign warships unless an assurance is received that they are not carrying nuclear weapons; and to require that foreign warships participating in the anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy not be carrying nuclear weapons in Australian territorial waters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Uranium mining and processing is dangerous to the health and well-being and ecology of the Earth and its citizens,
By-products of uranium are toxics for periods of up to 500,000 years, and are an intrinsic part of the production of nuclear weapons,
Existing safeguards are inadequate, and are not properly monitored.
The policy of the Australian Government permits the entry into Australian territory of vessels and aircraft without the assurance that they are not nuclear powered or armed,
Such vessels pose a threat to both the security and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
The presence of foreign military and communication bases on Australian soil seriously endangers the health and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable Senators will take cognisance of the above and take immediate action to remove the above dangers.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows support for a resolution passed at a Public Meeting held in Canberra on 29th October 1986, convened by the Council of Civil Liberties (ACT) and Rupert Public Interest Movement, calling on the Federal Government:
(i) To urgently restore the Australian Bill of Rights to the Parliamentary agenda with a view to enactment;
(ii) To give consideration to extending the Bill to the states and territories of Australia in the same was as the Commonwealth; and
(iii) To take the necessary steps to continue the operation of a Human Rights Commission from 9 December 1986.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned concerned Australian citizens here-by petition the Honourable Members and Senators to totally reject the current proposals for an I.D. Card and the proposed Data Protection Agency.

We believe that they represent potentially undesirable interference in the lives of honest Australians. Provisions for protection of privacy cannot be guaranteed as Statutes are easily altered by future Governments.

We believe that there are more efficient methods to prevent fraud in the areas of Social Security and taxation without the use of these two proposals, which go well beyond the reach of the true role of democratic government, i.e. That citizens may live quiet and peaceable lives. The I.D. Card and Data Protection Agency have strong potential under this or future administrations to interfere with the quiet and peaceable lives of its subjects.
We your humble petitioners in duty bound ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 18 citizens) and Haines (from 41 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:-
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combatting the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
(4) That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned are seriously concerned about the impact of the Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. It is unjust for any person to be liable for tax on benefits received by another person.
2. Compliance with FBT will increase administrative costs for all employers, including Local, State and Federal Government Departments.
3. FBT is an inefficient tax, which will require the Tax Office to employ an army of bureaucrats.
4. FBT is inequitable because liability arises regardless of capacity to pay.
5. The FBT laws are extremely complex.
We therefore most earnest petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from four citizens) and Sir John Carrick (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combatting the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
(4) That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The humble Petition of Citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the World in their efforts to achieve a Nuclear Free South Pacific, and such Decision being endorsed by the people at a General Election.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the United States Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on Nuclear Vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its Policy to promote the development of Zones of Peace and Nuclear Free Zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Alleged War Criminals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
If there is to be legal process against alleged war criminals resident in Australia, the foundations of justice should be clear and equitable.
1. Let the term, ``war crime'', be first clearly defined.
2. Let specific prosecutions be swiftly launched against those individuals alleged to have committed them, thus releasing the rest of their co-nationals from unwarranted slur and suspicion.
3. Let an Australian tribunal hear the charges. Nobody should be deported to face the ``tender mercies'' of any foreign government.
4. Let the presumption of innocence until proved guilt be clearly established.
5. Let all evidence obtained from the Soviet or any other communist government be set aside and totally disregarded.

6. Let all the costs of any person charged and found not guilty be paid by the Commonwealth Government so that innocent people are not financially ruined in the course of establishing their innocence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Plant Variety Rights Bill 1986, now before Parliament, should be withdrawn because:
1. There is growing concern about the economic concentration of the seed industry and the loss of traditional food plant varieties in overseas countries with this legislation.
2. Genes, seeds and other plant genetic material should remain a public resource.
3. The demand for uniformity, imposed by P.V.R. legislation, reduces genetic variability and could lead to the loss of traditional genetic material.
4. P.V.R. will discourage the free exchange of information, seeds and genetic material and is therefore likely to adversely affect Australia's public breeding programmes.
5. Our choice of food, its quality and nutritional value will increasingly be determined by the interests of large overseas companies rather than those of the Australian consumer.
6. There is no requirement in the bill for superiority or for merit testing of varieties to protect the interests of our farmers.
7. The bill can be interpreted to allow the registering of ``discoveries'' of previously unknown Australian native plants, many of which may have great social and/or economic value.
8. P.V.R. will mean higher costs for the farmer and the consumer and an increased burden on the Australian taxpayer.
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament recognise the widespread community opposition to P.V.R. and promote alternative incentives for plant breeding in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATURE CONSERVATION (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1986PUBLIC SERVICE BOARD DETERMINATION NO. 81 OF 1986

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notices of Motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in my name for three sitting days hence, concerning disallowance of the Nature Conservation (Amendment) Ordinance 1986 and Public Service Board Determination No. 81 of 1986. I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nature Conservation (Amendment) Ordinance provides for the preparation of plans of management for reserved areas in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee was concerned that the Ordinance did not provide sufficient opportunity for Parliament to oversee the declaration of such areas and making of such plans which can have long term effects. The Committee expressed its concern to the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and he agreed to provide for the tabling and disallowance of plans of management, declarations of reserved areas, and wilderness zones. The Committee thanks the Minister for his undertaking in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service Board Determination No. 81 was made retrospective for 18 months in order to pay certain allowances to employees. The explanatory statement did not explain the need for such extensive retrospectivity in delegated legislation. The Committee expressed its concern to the Chairman of the Public Service Board, who explained to the Committee's satisfaction why retrospectivity was needed in this case. He also undertook to ensure that, in future, statements would contain proper explanations for lengthy retrospectivity. Such an initiative will greatly facilitate the Committee's scrutiny. The Committee thanks the Board for its assistance in this regard. In keeping with the Committee's usual practice I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's correspondence on these two matters.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
The Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P.
Minister for Territories
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 13 November 1986, the Committee considered the Nature Conservation (Amendment) Ordinance 1986 (being A.C.T. Ordinance No. 65 of 1986, tabled in the Senate on 23 October 1986). The Committee seeks your comments and advice on the question of parliamentary control of plans of management and declarations of reserved areas for the A.C.T.

Under new sub-section 52G of the Principal Ordinance the Minister may revoke a declaration that an area is to be a reserved area under sub-section 51 (1). That revocation is, of course, quite properly made the subject of positive parliamentary oversight. Section 52H provides for tabling and disallowance of the gazetted revocation notice which may not come into operation until the day after the last day on which relevant parliamentary proceedings could have been taken but were not.

The Committee notes however, that the actual declaration of a reserve under section 51 does not appear to be subject to any parliamentary procedures. Also, there appears to be no similar parliamentary control over adoption, amendment or revocation of the plans of management referred to under section 52A and 52B. The Committee understands that because of their important environmental nature and far-reaching national implications, analogous declarations and plans are normally subject to tabling and disallowance. This is certainly the case regarding plans of management under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 (section 12), plans of management under the Fisheries Act 1952 (section 7C), zoning plans for marine parks under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 (section 75) and modifications or variations to the plan of lay-out of Canberra under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 (section 12A).

The Committee may have overlooked the relevant tabling and disallowance provision. In any event the Committee has been unable to draw any distinction of degree or kind between the plans referred to above, over which Parliament has provided that it shall exercise final control and the plans referred to in the Nature Conservation (Amendment) Ordinance 1986, over which the Parliament may have no control as a result of an Executive decision.

The Committee is at present of the view that it would be contrary to principle for A.C.T. plans of management and declarations of reserved areas, and amendments and revocations of them, to be placed beyond the scope of parliamentary control by means of an Ordinance not providing for such control. The Committee is surprised that no such provisions are easily identifiable and acknowledges that its advisers may well have overlooked the provisions providing for such important procedures.
The Committee would greatly appreciate your comments and advice on this significant issue.
Yours sincerely,
Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senator B. Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Cooney,
Thank you for your letter of 18 November 1986 concerning the A.C.T. Nature Conservation (Amendment) Ordinance 1986.

The power under the Nature Conservation Ordinance to declare reserved areas and approve plans of management for them is vested in me as Minister. The amendment in question was intended to ensure that a decision to declare a reserved area, once made, should not be lightly departed from. This is done by enabling either House of the Parliament to disallow the revocation of a declaration.

I agree that the initial declaration of a reserve area and the adoption of a management plan for the area are also executive acts of considerable significance. By analogy with modifications to the plan of lay-out of Canberra, under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, there is a case for these executive decisions also to be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny.

Therefore I propose to have the Ordinance amended to extend the power of disallowance to declarations of reserved areas (section 51). I also consider that declarations of wilderness zones (section 52) should be subject to disallowance, as should management plans for reserved areas (sections 52A and 52B).
Where I amend or revoke plans under section 52F, my decision will also be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny.

I consider it desirable that either House, instead of exercising the power to disallow a plan of management, should be able to recommend amendments of the plan to me, and in that event a plan which I have so amended will be subject to the further scrutiny of Parliament.
I trust that the foregoing meets the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely,
GORDON SCHOLES
Dr Peter Wilenski
Chairman
Public Service Board
McLachlan Offices
BARTON, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Dr Wilenski,

At its meeting on 20 November 1986, the Committee considered Public Service Board Determination No. 81 of 1986 (tabled in the Senate on 11 November 1986). The Committee seeks your assistance with one important matter relating to retrospectivity. The Determination is made retrospective to 25 May 1985, a period of almost 18 months. However, there is no explanation in the accompanying Explanatory Statement to explain the need for this retrospectivity which, the Committee notes, is beneficial to Commonwealth employees.

It has generally been the practice for many years in Defence Determinations that either the Explanatory Statement or a separate ministerial letter to the Committee, explains why retrospectivity is needed, particularly where retrospectivity of more than six months is involved.

In its Twenty-fifth Report (PP 188/1969, page 225) the Committee set out guidelines observed by it in its examination of delegated legislation which is retrospective. Thus, the Committee's legal adviser makes a special examination and report on all instruments which are retrospective because such legislation will prima facie attract the attention of the Committee and be subject to close scrutiny where payment of money is involved.

In that Report, the Committee wrote that it ``regards retrospectivity beyond a few months as objectionable. It is recognised, for obvious practical reasons of an admi-nistrative character, that some retrospectivity is inevit-able. The Committee believes that such retrospectivity should be of the shortest period practicable.''

These guidelines have been adopted by the Committee under successive administrations and have been repeated in numerous subsequent reports including the Seventy-seventh and Eightieth Reports (PP 172 and 241/1986).
The Committee would be grateful if you could advise why retrospectivity was needed in this particular case.
Yours sincerely,
Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations
and Ordinances
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney,

I refer to your letter dated 25 November 1986 to Dr Wilenski regarding Public Service Board Determination No. 81 of 1986. You requested advice as to why retro- spectivity was needed in the operation of the Deter- mination as the Explanatory Memorandum was silent on that aspect.

The Determination provided an allowance for certain employees of the Royal Australian Mint engaged in asbestos removal work. The allowance was determined following consideration of representations by the Royal Australian Mint that these employees were engaged in work equivalent to that performed by employees in another area in respect of whom the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had awarded an allowance.

The claim raised new issues and the Public Service Board needed to satisfy itself not only of the merits of this particular case but also the way in which it related to the broader framework within which the Board's pay policy operates, namely compliance with the National Wages Case principles. In addition, asbestos and its removal are sensitive industrial and occupational health and safety issues and the subject matter of the claim therefore had general ramifications which needed to be considered.

As a consequence of these considerations the Board's examination of the claim took some time. During this period the employees were carrying out the asbestos removal work and in these circumstances the Board believed that prospective payment of the allowance would have been to their disadvantage. The employees concerned are not covered by an award of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

As Mr Glenn indicated in his letter to you of 7 October 1986 regarding the Board's determination- making power under section 8B of the Public Service Act, the Board shares the Committee's concern about the potential problems arising where a determination has retrospective effect. However, as recognised by the Committee's Twenty-fifth Report to which you referred in your letter, there are indeed often practical reasons of an administrative character which make a degree of retrospectivity inevitable. For example, increases in rates of allowance are often implemented following an increase awarded by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Such awards frequently have retrospective operation. Other changes flow from agreements negotiated with staff associations. It is quite possible that a retrospective implementation date will form part of a negotiated agreement.
In future the Board will ensure that reasons for retrospective operation of determinations are adequately addressed in the accompanying memoranda.
Yours sincerely
Peter Kennedy
Acting Commissioner

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee reported progress last night we were discussing, if discussing is the right word, the definition of `associated technology' in clause 4 of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill. I had been particularly concerned about the situation of private nuclear research by academic research workers in a university, particularly in relation to a matter of great difference between the Government and Opposition, namely, Australia's role in the development of the nuclear fuel cycle, and particularly the enrichment of uranium for peaceful purposes. The Government's policy is very much opposed to that. It has directed that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, soon to become known as ANSTO, in short, should not pursue enrichment research in Australia or pursue the subject of enrichment with any commercial development in mind. The Opposition has a fundamentally different view from that of the Government about that matter. When we were in government we actively pursued the development of the uranium enrichment industry in Australia and considerable progress was being made in that direction when we went out of government in March 1983. The concern that we in the Opposition have about this legislation is that this Bill, under this Government's policies, may be used to prevent private research in this respect in Australia, either in universities or in companies which may be interested in the future. On our return to government they may wish to resume this development, which is of great economic significance to Australia. Great economic benefit is being denied to Australians by this Government's irrational policy dictated by its loony Left and encouraged by people in this chamber such as Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine and a few others of that ilk outside the chamber. It is a very important issue that I have raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased that, despite a certain irritation that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) seemed to feel last night when I raised this matter, he did say very clearly on behalf of the Government that the Government's policy would be to permit this type of research and development activity to take place in Australia, provided it was within the confines that I have mentioned, namely, for peaceful purposes and not in any way a covert means of diversion to purposes such as the development of nuclear weaponry, to which of course the Opposition is totally opposed. I applaud the answer that I received last night, albeit with some difficulty, from Senator Evans.

My other concern is that people in that situation, probably in universities-the most likely place where this might occur-should be aware of the possible application of this legislation to them. They should be aware that they should apply for a permit and that the Government will, in accordance with what Senator Evans has said, grant the permit providing it is satisfied that the research is all genuine. We also had the assurance from Senator Evans last night that the Government would not be bureaucratic and would not hold people up, that the administration would be smooth. All these things, hopefully, would be carried out if this matter was put to the test.

However, in the light of the answers I received from Senator Evans, I still have some concern. He was somewhat reluctant to give a clear-cut definition of what the Government meant by the wide definition of `associated technology'. He hedged his bets a bit in the answer he gave me on that. It may be that if the Government were to inform universities or people interested in this area in similar terms, they would not be very must assisted in knowing what to do. Apparently the universities have all been advised of this Bill and its application to them. I would be interested in seeing the terms of the Government's advice, the document that has been circulated to them. If such a document is available I would be pleased if Senator Evans would table it, either in this debate or as soon as possible, so we can see just how they have been advised on this matter. It may well be that they should be advised further in the light of last night's statement by Senator Evans in answer to my questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been listening to this particular point of discussion for probably some 45 minutes. What Senator Durack is actually asking would be the equivalent of trying to ask the people framing legislation for motor drivers licences exactly how each licence would be issued. He wants a detailed analysis of how each permit will be issued. There can be no such answer. The only conclusion I can draw from this is that Senator Durack loves to hear the sound of his own voice. Over and over again the Minister has explained this matter. I am afraid that Senator Durack did not bother to examine in Hansard the Minister's explanations, which have been lucid. Senator Durack has been on the same point, hammering away and wasting the time of the Committee. At this time I will not waste the time of the Committee any more except to point out that we have important legislation before us. This is an important piece of legislation-we have other pieces such as plant variety rights. I urge Senator Durack to do some homework so that we can get on with the business of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Sanders for his contribution although I am not sure that it will serve any purpose in calming down Senator Durack. I do not think that I can add a great deal to what I said last night. As far as the definition of `associated technology' is concerned, obviously questions will arise in practice as to whether or not it is applicable to a particular situation. All I can do is repeat that the correspondence that has already gone from the Australian Safeguards Office to the universities-I am afraid I do not have a copy of it with me-was, I am advised, correspondence which spelt out the language of that definition and asked universities and others to whom it was directed to get in touch with the ASO if they thought there was anything in their possession in the nature of this kind of technology, as well as material and equipment, which satisfied the definition. In that case there would be further discussions, and decisions would be made as to whether a permit was required and, if so, in what terms.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated, as yet there has not been any response to that letter, as far as I am advised, from anyone who thinks that he might come within the realm of the definition. If, as a result of this debate and the further stimulus that Senator Durack has given the issue, there is such a response it will be dealt with sensibly and in accordance with the spirit of the legislation-I assure him and anyone else interested-by the Government. I make the further point which I did not make last night that if anyone is unhappy about the application of the permit requirement to something which that person thinks does not come within the terms of the legislation, or is unhappy in particular if a permit should be refused in relation to something which clearly comes within the terms of the legislation, in either event appeal is available to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal under the terms of this legislation. So this is not just a matter of people being subject to the discretionary whim of the Government; there are appropriate administrative appeals procedures which will enable the issue to be resolved.

I do not want to get into a debate on the larger issue of uranium enrichment technology and whether it is appropriate for that to be pursued. I simply make the point, as I have done on other occasions, that the enrichment technology that was being pursued by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission was the centrifugal technology which may still have a continued use in the future notwithstanding the latter day enthusiasm for laser technology of enrichment. Even within the area of centrifugal enrichment technology the evidence seems to be that the Commission's research was lagging a number of years behind comparable research in other countries. For that reason it does not seem likely that there will be any chance of immediate commercial spin-offs, even in the absence of the Government's concern for policy reasons, to which Senator Durack adverts, about Australian participation in this kind of research. That is really a debate for another occasion.

This legislation clearly is designed not to inhibit research in any way but simply to ensure that if there is to be any research, and more particularly communication of that research, which is of proliferation significance and sensitivity, because of Australia's international obligations to supervise such matters it will be necessary for it to come within the terms of this regulatory arrangement. That is why the matter comes up. It is not because of any particular desire on our part to pursue other policy objectives through this legislation. On the contrary, the objectives of this Bill are as I have described them. I thank Senator Durack for his acknowledgment that I have answered as best I can the question he raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I express my satisfaction with Senator Gareth Evans's approach on the subject last night as well as this morning. I do not think we can take that matter any further. However, I ask that the letter that was sent to all institutions be made available. I think it ought to be tabled or incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to do that. Mr Chairman, while I am on my feet and since we are considering the Bill as a whole, it might now be an appropriate point for me to move the amendments standing in the name of the Government. I seek leave to move together the amendments to clauses 22 and 23, the addition of a sub-clause in clause 26 and the further addition of a sub-clause in clause 72.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 20, clause 22, line 7, leave out ``(1) or''.
(2) Page 21, clause 23, at the end of the clause add the following sub-clause:
``(6) Sub-section (1) does not apply to the possession of associated technology by a Commonwealth officer in the course of-
(a) the performance of a function or duty, or the exercise of a power, under the Patents Act 1952 or regulations under the Act; or

(3) Page 23, clause 26, at the end of the clause add the following sub-clause:
``(4) Sub-section (1) does not apply to the communication of information by a Commonwealth officer in the course of-

(4) Page 46, clause 72, at the end of the clause add the following sub-clauses:

``(4) Without limiting the generality of sub-section (1), the Minister may delegate to the Director the Minister's power to grant permits under section 13 or 16 or to grant authorities under section 18.
``(5) If the Minister delegates to the Director the Minister's power to grant permits under section 13 or 16, the following provisions have effect:

(b) sections 14 and 15 do not apply in relation to any application for a permit that is dealt with by the Director pursuant to the delegation but the Director-

``(6) If the Minister delegates to the Director the Minister's power to grant authorities under section 18, the following provisions have effect:

(b) sub-section 18 (2) does not apply in relation to an application for an authority that is dealt with by the Director pursuant to the delegation but the Director shall not grant an authority unless the Director is satisfied that the person applying for the grant of the authority has provided the Director with all information that the Director has required the person to provide in relation to the application pursuant to paragraph 17 (2) (a).''.

I table the explanatory memorandum relating to those amendments, and simply mention that I believe they are all uncontroversial and, for reference, they either address particular matters of concern raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee or deal with a particular question that arose about the exemption of the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office from the permit requirement, which again appears to be uncontroversial, or relate to the procedural matter about delegation, which is equally in that category. One further matter is that I seek leave to amend the text of one of those amendments. There, unfortunately, is a misprint. The second amendment, which refers to sub-clause (6) (a) of clause 23, refers in its last line to `regulations under the Act'; the language should read `regulations under that Act'. The reference is to the Patents Act 1952.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four more amendments-three from the Opposition, which I think are all related, and one from the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Opposition amendments to which you have referred have been circulated. I think they are a code in themselves, and I seek leave to move them as such.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 10, after clause 8, insert the following clause in Part I:
Act not to apply to visiting allied forces
``8a. (1) This Act does not apply in relation to-
(a) ships, aircraft or equipment of a visiting allied force;
(b) a member of a visiting allied force acting in accordance with the member's duty; or
(c) a member of the Defence Force or a Commonwealth officer associated with a visiting allied force acting in accordance with the member's or the officer's duty.

``(2) In this section, `visiting allied force' means an armed force of a foreign country declared by the Minister, by notice in writing published in the Gazette, to be a visiting allied force for the purposes of this section.

``(3) A certificate, signed by the Minister, certifying that a member of the Defence Force or a Commonwealth officer is or was associated with a visiting allied force or is or was acting in accordance with the member's or the officer's duty is evidence of the facts stated in the certificate.

``(4) Where the Minister considers that it is necessary, for the purpose of preventing, detecting or investigating an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, or for the purpose of proceedings in relation to such an offence, that a provision of this Act apply in relation to a person or thing referred to in sub-section (1), the Minister may, by notice in writing published in the Gazette, declare that a provision of this Act so applies to the extent and for the time specified in the notice, and the provision shall apply accordingly.''.
(2) Page 28, after sub-clause 40 (1), insert the following sub-clause:

``(1a) Where, at any time before or during the hearing of proceedings before a court in relation to an offence against this Act, there is submitted to the Judge or Magistrate a certificate signed by the Minister certifying that the proceedings involve or may involve matters relating to-
(a) ships, aircraft or equipment of a visiting allied force;
(b) a member of a visiting allied force; or
(c) a member of the Defence Force or a Commonwealth officer associated with a visiting allied force,
the Judge or Magistrate shall make orders-
(d) that all members of the public be excluded during the proceedings;
(e) that no report of the proceedings be published; and

(f) prohibiting access, before, during or after the proceedings, to any affidavit, exhibit, information or other document used in the proceedings that is on the file in the court or in the records of the court.''.
(3) Page 28, sub-clause 40 (2), after ``sub-section (1)'', insert ``or (1a)''.

The Opposition regards the first amendment very seriously indeed. It deals with a matter which I raised in my remarks on the second reading of this Bill. Although I also raised the question of the effect of this Bill on private academic research, as I have said, I have been satisfied that no suitable amendment is possible to cover that question. That is why I have been at some pains to have the Minister express the Government's attitude to the way it will administer that definition of `associated technology'. However, in the case of the other major matter of concern to the Opposition, namely, the way this legislation may affect our defence arrangements, the Opposition believes than an amendment along the lines which I have moved and to which I have referred is desirable and an effective amendment along those lines can be suitably incorporated into this legislation.

I am most conscious of the difficulties of this legislation. It is one of the most technically complicated pieces of legislation with which I have had to deal in my time in the Senate, including my time in government. It is complicated because it is dealing with a highly technical scientific subject which has many facets to it. We recently debated the enormously difficult scientific question of the difference between the development of enriched uranium for peaceful purposes as against weaponry. The Bill is difficult and the issues are difficult from a legal point of view. There are all sorts of reasons for this which, the Committee will no doubt be pleased to know, I do not propose to go into. But it is difficult and very complicated. A further complication is the fact that this legislation seeks to give effect in Australian domestic law to a number of treaty obligations in this area. In particular, of course, it seeks to give effect to the Treaty or the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons itself, the agency agreement that Australia has entered into with the International Atomic Energy Agency and, indeed, all of our bilateral safeguards agreements, as they are called, with countries with which we trade in respect of the export of uranium.

In particular, the difficulties which arise in the schedules set out in the back of the Bill have to be enmeshed and given effect to in domestic law. It is quite well known and understood, although it is perhaps not so easily extracted, that those international instruments are concerned only with the question of preventing the diversion of uranium used for peaceful purposes in the nuclear fuel cycle to the development of nuclear weaponry. The technical language which has evolved includes the term `safeguardable material'. `Safeguardable material' has a particular meaning which is understood by the experts, the cognoscenti, the apparatchiks and so on. They understand it is but it is very difficult for other people to understand it. In my view it might be even very difficult for judges to understand if they were ever called upon to interpret this legislation.

What this legislation is clearly not intended to deal with is the situation that could arise if an ally of Australia which possesses-and, as far as these international agreements are concerned, quite lawfully possesses-nuclear weapons either sent a warship into Australian waters or brought some nuclear material to this country. I know that one only has to mention this to get a reaction from a lot of people in this place. I can see that Senator Coleman is already looking daggers at me from across the chamber. I know that Senator Vallentine is listening to what I say. It is a wonder that Senator Sanders did not completely explode at even my mentioning this totally unmentionable thing. The fact of the matter is that, as the rest of us in this chamber understand, both Government and Opposition senators, an enormously important matter as far as Australia's defence is concerned is the ANZUS Treaty and the other no doubt less formal but traditional alliances with our other allies, some of which-and I am trying to be as neutral and as unprovocative as I possibly can-do in fact possess nuclear weapons. They have-horror of horrors-ships that carry nuclear weapons. They actually think that they have to cart these weapons around the world on ships. They also have nuclear powered ships and so on.

Whether or not some people like it, it happens to be the Government's policy to allow those ships to come to Australia, and indeed to welcome them. It is certainly also the Opposition's policy to do so. But as we well know, a number of people in Australia-some of whom are in this chamber and some of whom I have mentioned-take very active steps to protest about these visits. There is a very small and probably declining element in the Australian community who are prepared perhaps to go to very extreme steps to make their objections to this known and who, I suggest to the Government, would even be prone to taking legal steps to try to prevent this occurring.

It seems to me-I would be very interested to hear Senator Gareth Evans's views on this-that we could well have a situation where the interpretation of this legislation could be put in question, for very clear political reasons, by certain people in Australia. If that situation arose I think there would be difficulty. There may well be a difficulty in explaining to a court exactly what is intended by this legislation and by the international instruments to which it gives effect. There seems to be an extraordinary reluctance on the part of some judicial officers these days to give executive government very much of a hearing on certain matters. The Government had a very recent example of that in the New South Wales courts. I am concerned that we should make it clear as daylight that this legislation does not apply to our defence arrangements, particularly our defence arrangements dealing with our nuclear allies. For that reason I have moved the amendment that has been circulated in my name. I do not propose to read it-it speaks for itself anyway-and I hope that I have explained the Opposition's purpose and intention in moving it.

One other aspect of the second amendment, which may be more controversial than the first amendment, is that it deals with proceedings before a court relating to an alleged offence under this proposed Act-that is, the offence of possessing or transporting nuclear material-where the court should be closed. Again I know that there is a clause in the legislation which will give the courts powers to have a hearing in camera in relation to proceedings under this legislation. However, my objection to that is that it is giving a discretion to the courts. As I have already said, I am not happy about the way in which that might be exercised by some judicial officers. When all is said and done, these proceedings could take place in a great variety of jurisdictions, from the highest to the lowest. In view of the way in which some judicial officers have been exercising discretions in relation to very sensitive material-until recent years no court would ever have dreamt of questioning the bona fides of an executive order-and in view of the developments in that area, I am not prepared to see these discretions in relation to such sensitive matters left to judges. Therefore, I think it ought to be quite clearly laid down in the legislation in this way. For that reason, I have moved the amendment standing in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to voice my complete opposition to the amendments suggested by Senator Durack concerning what he euphemistically calls Australia's defence arrangements which would allow forever free entry to nuclear warships coming to Australian ports. He makes nuclear weapons sound almost friendly, harmless, and very welcome in our ports. I remind Senator Durack that nuclear weapons are for fighting nuclear wars. That has very clearly been said by the New Zealand people over and over again who have rejected the entry of nuclear weapons bearing warships into their ports. That is the purpose of building nuclear weapons. Deterrence is a myth and any sensible person knows that. There is no known weapons system in the history of humanity that has not been used eventually. We are playing with the fate of the earth if we continue to allow nuclear weapons to be built and to come into our ports. It is absolute insanity.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack would like to paint the opponents of nuclear weapons coming into Australian ports as extremists. We are not extremists; we are very reasonable human beings who are concerned about the fate of the future of this planet. We are not prepared to jeopardise the future of this planet and the future of our children by allowing such dangerous weapons to come into our ports. As I said yesterday, neither are we such a small minority group as Senator Durack would like to suggest. It is a growing minority of Australian people, soon to become a majority, who will oppose nuclear weapons coming into our ports.

I remind Senator Durack, members of the Opposition and members of the Government that there are millions of Americans who refuse to allow nuclear weapons to go into highly populated American ports. The case of nuclear reactors going into American ports such as New York and San Francisco does not even arise and yet we allow nuclear reactors to come into certain Australian ports, or very close to them in the case of Fremantle. That situation does not even arise in the United States of America. The question about nuclear reactors going into highly populated American ports is not even asked. Nuclear weapons on board United States warships are not welcome either in many American ports. I will give one example only to illustrate that point.

For over three years a debate has been raging in New York about the home porting of the USS Iowa, one of the Second World War warships that has been brought out of mothballs and fitted with Tomahawk cruise missiles-a most destabilising nuclear weapons system to be put on board any ship, surface or submarine. The people of New York reject having the USS Iowa home ported in New York because they realise the extreme danger to the city of New York should there be an accident with one of the weapons on board that or any other warship in the harbour of New York. It is total lunacy to allow these weapons to come into our harbours. Environmentally they are extremely dangerous. Accidents do happen. We are stupid in the extreme if we allow our people to be put at risk when the American people in highly populated ports do not allow themselves to be put at a comparable risk. Why on earth should Australians put themselves at that kind of risk?

We are concerned not only about the environmental risks however; the major concern of people who oppose the visits of nuclear warships to our ports is a moral one. As well as being concerned about our health, the welfare of our people and our environment, we are concerned about the moral implications of allowing nuclear weapons into our ports. As I have said, nuclear weapons are for fighting nuclear wars, and many Australians are opposed to Australia having any involvement at all in that. Mainly for that reason, I totally object to the Opposition's amendments to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also reject the Opposition's amendments because nuclear disasters respect no nationalities or national boundaries. Why should we exempt some nuclear material coming into our harbours simply because it happens to be American and have safeguards over others? The argument was brought up by Senator Durack that somehow this legislation would affect our defence arrangements. I do not know on what he bases his contention because I doubt very much whether he has had direct communication with the planners in the United States of America on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had occasion to write a letter to the Center for Defense Information-CDI-in Washington, DC, which consists of a group of retired admirals, generals and people from other military ranks from the Navy, the Marine Corps and the Army who have joined together in a campaign to eliminate nuclear weapons. They understand that nuclear weapons are not usable in modern war because once a person uses a nuclear weapon, he has lost the war, his country and, perhaps, the earth. They realised that they are not viable weapons. I asked this specific question: What is the strategic or military necessity for nuclear armed and powered ships coming into Australian ports? The answer I received was compiled by Captain James T. Bush, a retired United States Navy captain, who is Associate Director of the Center for Defense Information. He stated:

As a naval officer with 25 years experience in naval operations, including service as Executive Officer of two submarines and Commander of the USS Simon Bolivar, a nuclear-powered submarine, I can say with confidence that port visits have nothing to do with training naval forces for combat operations at sea. Port visits are wonderful opportunities for rest, recreation and personal adventures, but they don't contribute to military readiness.

I repeat: Rest, recreation and personal adventure. Maybe those sailors would like to see Kings Cross, but it is not necessary militarily or strategically for those nuclear armed and powered ships to enter our harbours. He continued:

I would like to add that the U.S. Navy's neither confirm nor deny policy cannot be justified on the basis of denying information to the Soviet Union. The extensive publicly available information about the U.S. Navy's nuclear arsenal plus Soviet intelligence capabilities means that if anyone knows which U.S. ships are likely carrying nuclear weapons, it is the Soviets.
The former captain in the United States Navy-and I urge Senator Durack to listen-stated:

Australia, like New Zealand, is more than entitled to exercise its right to make its nation a nuclear free zone if it wishes. This is particularly the case when this right can be respected without detriment to the military readiness or national security of any of the parties to the ANZUS treaty.

Those are the words of a former captain in the United States Navy. So the denial of the right of passage to nuclear armed and powered ships to our ports will have no strategic impact whatsoever. These amendments are not necessary; in fact, they are harmful. The proposed sub-clause which would close courts during hearings on these matters is particularly abhorrent. What we need is more information on nuclear matters, not less. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make clear what is the Government's position before the debate proceeds further. The Government's policy on access to Australian ports by ships of allied forces that may or may not contain nuclear weapons is well known. There is no question of the Government accepting any of the reasoning, if it may be so described, of Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine in their approach to the Opposition's amendments. Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine seem to assume that without the amendments the legislation, as it presently stands, could somehow be construed as prohibiting or in some way hindering the access of such ships. As a result, Senator Durack's amendments, which are designed to remove any such hindrance are, for that reason, opposed by Senator Vallentine and Senator Sanders.

SPEECH.PARA: The starting point for the Government's approach to this is quite different. We accept, as I say, the propriety of such ship visits occurring. It is a necessary incident of an alliance relationship. Whatever we may think about the desirability of removing nuclear weapons from the face of the globe, which is an aspiration that we, of course, share with Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine, the present state of the nuclear balance is such that that is obviously not possible at the moment. While we are in the process of achieving that desirable millennium, there is, in the Government's view, a need for nuclear deterrence and that means necessarily access to nuclear weapons and the carriage of nuclear weapons by allied naval forces and, in some instances, military aircraft as well. That is the starting point.

Our approach to this legislation is that there is no need for Senator Durack's amendments to immunise allied forces from the operation of the legislation because they are already immunised from its application by virtue of the common law doctrine of sovereign immunity. There is simply no question of this legislation being applicable to a visiting allied force, and that threshold objection could and would be taken right at the outset of any court proceedings that might be attempted to be set by anyone who wanted to use this legislation, as Senator Durack indicated might conceivably occur, to put barriers in the way of the visits of such forces. If such litigation were to be initiated, either in civil or criminal jurisdiction, the procedural objection could readily be taken with a certain prospect of success. It is not necessary to get into the question of closing courts in order that the nature of the technology or whatever involved might be the subject of scrutiny behind closed doors. Without needing to do any of those things a straightforward procedural objection could be taken which would undoubtedly be upheld.

Furthermore, so far as individual military personnel are concerned, as distinct from the allied country itself, they are already immune from prosecution for actions pursuant to their duties by virtue of the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963. So that combination-the common law doctrine plus that explicit statutory protection-in the circumstances of the operation of this legislation we believe is sufficient not to require any explicit amendments of the kind that Senator Durack is proposing.

I might say that this issue was considered in very close detail in the course of the preparation of this Bill, and a lot of consultation occurred between my Department, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Defence and the Attorney-General's Department in order that there might be agreement on this particular matter, because there is no doubt that we share the views that have been expressed by Senator Durack as to what ought to be the case so far as the application of this legislation is concerned. We were absolutely ad idem on that; it is just a question of whether or not there is any need to go further.

If we do go further and try to put it in legislative form in circumstances where we are doing no more than, in a quite redundant way, dealing with a situation that will not in practice arise, other problems do show up. The certificate procedure that Senator Durack's amendment envisages is clearly premised on the assumption that any visiting allied force or ship may well be nuclear armed. For us to issue a certificate or to apply the gazettal provision in the way that this amendment envisages would be no doubt construed, in some quarters at least, as an acknowledgment or an assertion by the Australian Government that the ship or task group in question was in fact nuclear armed; yet, of course, under the `no confirm or deny' policy no such assumption can be made and certainly the Government does not want to get itself into a position of doing anything which could be construed as drawing conclusions which are inconsistent with that `no confirm or deny' approach of our allies.

Again, there is a further problem-perhaps it is a minor one-in that the exemption for members of the Australian defence forces and Commonwealth officers associated with a visiting allied force creates perhaps in some people's minds the inference that Australian personnel may well be in possession or control of, or have access to, nuclear material and technology of visiting forces and in some way be thus, albeit indirectly, involved in actions which are manifestly contrary to this nation's, this Government's, policy of not ourselves having anything to do with nuclear weaponry. So we get into the sort of jungle of inferences being drawn. We get into the further problems that have already been adverted to about closing courts and the basic issues of principle that are involved whenever one goes down the particular path of closing courts to public access. I do not deny that there are circumstances where such closures are necessary, but this is not one of them, by reason, I repeat, of the application of the common law doctrine of sovereign immunity, which we are all absolutely satisfied, having had a careful look at it and taken the best available advice, would apply as a threshold objection to any possible attempt to make this legislation applicable in the circumstances to which Senator Durack referred. In those circumstances-and not for any of the reasons, with the utmost respect, advanced by Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine-the Government does not accept the Opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the safety of nuclear armed ships in port compared with the safety of conventionally armed ships. I have made a few inquiries about this matter and discussed it with ballistic experts. I understand that if a ship is armed with nuclear weapons those weapons are not attached to the trigger mechanism which is required to make that weapon a dangerous ha-zard. The trigger mechanism is not attached until the extremely unlikely event of that particular weapon being used in active warfare. On the other hand, the conventionally armed ship is far more hazardous because, when exposed to fire or accidental explosion, those weapons can explode. But that is not so with respect to nuclear armed ships. I thought that I would make that comment because some of the arguments used on this topic are somewhat fallacious when confronted with advice from ballistic experts.

—I would like to correct that. I have never said that nuclear weapons are likely to accidentally explode; let me make that clear. I have said that they are dangerous, but have never said that they would accidentally explode. I agree with Senator Jessop's point that they are not triggered for explosion, but they are subject, as are conventional weapons, to fire. They are subject to fire and to implosion if the vessels are rammed, if there is a collision, and then the radioactive substances would leak out. Is Senator Jessop so stupid as to suggest that that would be less dangerous than a fire from a conventional weapon? Maybe Senator Jessop does not understand the qualitative difference between conventional weaponry and nuclear weaponry. The results of an accident with a nuclear weapon by fire or by collision would be absolutely catastrophic in any city. This is the very reason why the citizens of New York and San Francisco will not allow nuclear weapons to go into their harbours. There is a qualitative difference, which perhaps some Opposition senators do not understand, in the kinds of results that would occur if there were a fire on board ships carrying nuclear weapons and the nuclear weapons were ignited. I am not saying that they would explode accidentally; I have never said that and I do not like the inference drawn by Senator Jessop. That is a misrepresentation of the point. I have never said that they would accidentally explode, but I do say that, if they were to catch fire or to be damaged by collision, radioactive substances would leak out and cause contamination such as would never result from any kind of conventional weapon fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to go into a debate on nuclear weapons technology, particularly with such an uninformed audience as we have on the other side and among the Australian Democrats at the moment, but some outrageously ignorant statements need to be corrected for the public record.
—What would you know about this?

—A hell of a lot more than you do, Senator Sanders. Current generation nuclear weapons possessed by the United States and by the Western powers are infinitely safer than they were a generation ago. There have been enormous advances in the safety inherent in the storage and transport of those weapons. In the early 1960s when an American Strategic Air Command aircraft crashed near Malaga in Spain the clean up program ran for years. It involved the removal of soil from the Spanish countryside as a consequence of radiation from the crash of that aircraft with nuclear weapons on board. Such a thing cannot happen today. Despite what Senator Vallentine says, one can burn nuclear bombs and nuclear missiles and not have a problem. The design of the casing is so good that those disasters are now avoided. As Senator Jessop said, they do not explode accidentally. I would be much more concerned about having a ship like the USS Missouri, if I were concerned at all. I am prepared to accept that risk because it is so low as to be minimal, but one is much more at risk having a conventionally armed battleship tied up in Sydney with its load of conventional high explosives than one is with a modern United States warship with nuclear weapons on board.

SPEECH.PARA: As for all this claptrap about ships in American harbours, I was in San Francisco last month. The nuclear powered aircraft carrier USS Enterprise is in dry dock in San Francisco at present. In San Francisco harbour there are nuclear capable cruisers and destroyers. Their weapons are on board and there is no objection from the council or good citizens of San Francisco-which, after San Diego, is probably the second biggest United States navy port on the West Coast. I think that the Enterprise probably is disarmed with respect to nuclear weapons while it is in dry dock, but I do not think the weapons would be terribly far away. Let us have enough of this fear tactic and preying on the ignorance of the Australian people. Let us go into a few facts in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Committee for very long, but would like to point out that all these impossible things were said about Windscale-it was impossible that there would ever be a disaster there. It was a billion to one chance that there would ever be the Three Mile Island disaster. It was a billion to one chance that there would ever be the Chernobyl disaster. We are always told that these things are impossible, and when they happen it is said: `Oh well, these things just happen'. It turns out that the most likely form of accident which could happen anywhere with a nuclear weapon is not the detonation of the bomb itself but the detonation of the high explosive detonator, which, after all, is subject to all the difficulties of high explosives. If the detonator exploded the bomb would not, there would be no sustainable chain reaction, but the plutonium in the bomb would be widely dispersed into the environment. This is a finite danger.

SPEECH.PARA: Another danger which has not been mentioned is the human element. These things have a number of failsafe devices but, given the stress that military personnel are sometimes under, the high use of alcohol and of dope in the military, which is still happening today unfortunately, it is conceivable with a smaller weapon that an irate, misguided or unhinged person could, perhaps with someone else and for spite, detonate a weapon. It is possible; it is not impossible. This is another reason for keeping these weapons away from our shores.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did talk about the technology involved in weapons, but there has been as much research put into human behavioural actions and means of securing command and control of the weapons systems as has gone into the technology. People who handle nuclear weapons are very rigorously screened from a personality point of view; they undergo very rigorous training. There are all sorts of things like permissive active links which require complex and duplicated chains of command before the weapons can be detonated, let alone released. To go down that path is to show one's ignorance of contemporary nuclear technology. I come to a point that is very dear to the hearts of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party-that is, the comprehensive test ban treaty; the belief that if we ban the testing of nuclear weapons, which is attractive to a lot of us in many ways, somehow or other we will be safer. The need or ability to test nuclear weapons has resulted--

—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chair: I do not mind Senator MacGibbon having a word or two on the subject of the test ban treaty, but I suspect that in doing so he will stimulate another debate in this place. This point is of exceedingly marginal relevance to the Bill and the amendment now before us. I ask you to draw his attention to the question of relevance.
—I hope that I have not opened a Pandora's box on this, but quite simply the ability to test new generations of weapons has resulted in the far safer storage of those weapons than we have had.

—I suggest that the honourable senator is straying a little wide of the matter under discussion, which is the set of amendments before us. I draw that fact to the attention of the chamber generally. I am sure that there will be an opportunity to discuss the question of a nuclear test ban treaty on some other occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must make another point about a matter that Senator MacGibbon raised, not about the nuclear test ban treaty but about the personnel involved in handling the weapons. It is very important that this matter be addressed, even if briefly. Ex-Naval Commander Michael Lynch, who was in the Royal Australian Navy for 20 years and for 2 1/2 years was in charge of naval visits to Western Australia before his retirement, had a great deal to do with the people who came off the submarines and other nuclear ships. He said that the more he saw of these people the more he became concerned about their mental welfare. This applied particularly to those who came off the nuclear submarines. They had been at sea, under water, for something like 60 days or more and he said that when they came off those ships they were like walking zombies. They had their five to seven days leave in the port and when they got back on their ship having had, as Senator Sanders said earlier, their rest, recreation and other adventures, they were in an even worse state.
