DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment-
1. The capacity of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to:
(a) assess the environmental impact of proposed projects; and
(b) ensure the environmental sound management of such projects.

2. The adequacy and effectiveness of Australia's participation in the decision-making process of the international banks and multilateral aid agencies of which Australia is a member in relation to the environmental aspects of development projects.

The Australian Government funds many development projects overseas. It is involved in choosing, designing and implementing many of these. Many projects involve major changes in agricultural, forestry, fishery and rural development practices. As such they are projects which often have major conservation and environmental implications. In recent times there has emerged an increased awareness of these implications. Discussion has arisen in relation to the need for conservation and environmental issues to be considered by donor agencies when they are considering supporting proposed projects as well as during the implementation of projects.

The intention of this inquiry is to examine the environmental assessment policies of the donor agencies with which Australia is involved. The main agencies involved would include the Australian Development Assistance Bureau-ADAB-the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. ADAB is the agency responsible for the implementation of Australia's bilateral development assistance program. The World Bank has one of the biggest programs of rural and transmigration assistance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Messner, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, condemning the Hawke Labor Government for its mismanagement of the Australian economy which has resulted in-
(a) huge rises in the cost of living, particularly in food prices which have increased by 8.6 per cent for the 12 months to December 1986;

(b) the highest interest rate regime in the Western world, in particular, home loan interest rates which are at their highest levels since the Great Depression, resulting in a drastic downturn in home ownership in Australia;

(c) huge increases in the prices of motor vehicles of approximately 40 per cent since 1983 which are a direct result of misguided Government policies, the depreciation of the Australian dollar and the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, resulting in lower sales and reduced job opportunities;
(d) falling disposable incomes for the majority of Australians caused by higher taxes as taxpayers move into the higher Keating tax brackets;
(e) lack of job growth and continuing high levels of unemployment, particularly amongst our youth who are experiencing an unemployment rate between 21 and 23 per cent;
(f) continuing high current account deficits, averaging in excess of $1b. per month on our balance of payments caused by inappropriate cost containment policies;
(g) low levels of investment in new job creation industries such as import replacement and export industries;

(h) rapidly increasing foreign debt which has trebled since 1983, currently approximately $100b. and is estimated to increase by a further 50 per cent over the next 3 years unless Government policies are changed,

calls upon the Hawke Labor Government to introduce a mini-Budget to include lower and flatter rates of income tax, significant reductions in Government expenditure, and the abolition of the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and the lump-sum superannuation tax.

Because of the great concern of all Australians, and thus the Liberal-National Opposition, about the economic crisis inflicted upon us by the Hawke Labor Government, I am aware of a long list of honourable senators who wish to speak to the motion. By every known statistic Australia is in an economic crisis. Today I intend to speak briefly on some of the items raised in Senator Messner's motion and to allow my colleagues and those following to enlarge on those matters. I will touch just briefly on the cost of living. The cost of living, as measured by the consumer price index, is our inflation rate. In relation to Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, Australia is behind only New Zealand in regard to inflation rate levels. The inflation rate is close to 10 per cent, which is almost double digit inflation. More importantly, in relation to the cost of living, food prices in particular have increased by a factor of 8.6 per cent for the 12 months to December 1987.

We must compare the inflation rate in Australia with the rates in comparative countries. Let us look at some of those figures: In West Germany the rate is 0.2 per cent; in Switzerland, 0.7 per cent; in the United States of America, 2 per cent; in France, 2.7 per cent; in Great Britain, 3.4 per cent; and in Canada, 4.2 per cent. In fact, the big seven industrialised countries experienced an average rate of 2 per cent a year, compared with 3 per cent in 1985, so the rates in those countries have all dropped. I believe, from the figures that I have, that Australia was one of only four OECD countries to experience an increased inflation rate in the last 12 months.

Breadwinners, housekeepers, farmers and small businesses do not have to read official statistics to know that a great many of their number are now compelled to use their savings, if they are lucky enough to have any, to survive. Those without savings are living from hand to mouth. The only benefit of cost of living statistics is that individuals learn that their very real problems are not caused by their own inadequacies; they are shared by many other people in Australia. They are suffering because of policies that have been brought down by this Government. They are old socialist policies that have been tried in the past and found wanting, and are being tried yet again. The Government, in order to divert attention from the failures which it has inflicted upon us, and egged on by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in an attempt to blame someone else and to wash the blood from its collective hands, adopts another ploy and appoints a watchdog committee on prices. It is a transparent and cynical exercise which fools no one. Prices are established in a competitive market. The whole basis of advertising essential products such as food is based on price competitiveness. The same cannot be said of the monopolised, inflexible labour market.

Another critical factor is the level of interest rates. It is believed by most that interest rates will be the cause of death of the present Labor Government, just as it is causing the financial death of every family and every small business in this country. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who is at the table, has a habit of saying that the current sustained run of high interest rates has not reached the level experienced under the previous coalition Government. Let me lay that to rest once and for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-two per cent.

—Thank you, Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh referred to a solitary, short-lived blip in 90-day bank bills in early 1982. It is the classic use and abuse of statistics and, to some extent, can be categorised almost as statistical dishonesty. The interest rates which affect business, and thus investment and employment, are overdraft rates. The highest overdraft rate under the last coalition Government was 14.3 per cent in 1982-83. Since the Hawke Government came to power the figure has risen to a level of 10.5 per cent. With those sorts of interest rates, it is just not possible for businesses in Australia to compete with those in the rest of the world, where interest rates are far below 10 per cent. Of course, it is important to note that, in an international context, if interest rates are so high, the inability of the business sector to be able to carry out investments because of the level of interest rates affects the employment rate, the manufacturing industry, farmers and every small business.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point, of course, is the level of housing interest rates. Under the Hawke Labor Government housing interest rates have risen to over 15.5 per cent. This figure makes it absolutely impossible for young people in receipt of average weekly earnings to buy their own homes. Perhaps that is the Government's idea. Growing numbers are walking away from their homes because they just cannot afford the repayments. This is reflected in the growth in the number of claims lodged with the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

The other area that is affecting everyone is the level of taxation. Australians have been taxed into submission. The Hawke Labor Government has squeezed the taxpayer orange dry and is now trying to squeeze the pips. The tax reductions given late last year, and those to occur in June, if they do occur, have already been overtaken by bracket creep; that is, people are moving into higher tax brackets. What has happened to the amount of tax paid by a family man with a dependent wife and two children? Let me cite some figures. When the Hawke Government came to power in 1983, average weekly earnings were $366.53. That figure has risen, in 1986-87 estimates, to $441.28. Let us look at the amount of income tax paid by a man with a dependent spouse and two dependent children, with deductions. I think everyone should remember that the figure has changed as follows: In 1983-84, the amount of tax paid by a man in receipt of average weekly earnings was $2,743. In 1986-87 that figure will be $4,042. When the Hawke Government came to power, the percentage as a proportion of total earnings was 14.3 per cent. It is now 17.6 per cent. The figure we should look at is the marginal rate paid on the last dollar earned. When the Hawke Government came to power the marginal tax rate on the last dollar earned by a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two dependent children was 30.416c in the dollar. In 1986-87 the figure is 45.395c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder the people are revolting.

—Thank you, Senator Walters. I think people are at the end of their tether. It is not surprising, really, that their concern may be such that they are prepared to follow anyone who will offer them some relief, irrespective of the fact that perhaps the offers being made are snake oil. I will refer briefly to the current account deficit. The latest balance of payments surplus was $1.2 billion. The average figure is over $1 billion a month. Put simply, our exports are not paying for our imports. The collapse of our currency was supposed to solve our problems. The hypothesis of the J-curve theory-about which, to his credit, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, was very guarded-was put to me by Labor theorists. They say: `We will try to organise the dollar to collapse and it will solve all our problems'. The theory is that the dollar goes down, the value of our traditional exports goes up, manufacturers respond, we get import replacements and maybe we export some manufactured products and, presto, we have a cure-all for our balance of payments problems. It did not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that our terms of trade collapsed. But, as a person who was involved at one time in the export of commodities, that did not surprise me; the level at which our commodities are priced in an oversupplied market will deteriorate when there is a reduction in the dollar's value because the buyers are in the happy position of knowing that they can squeeze the price down. However, if one asks any manufacturer in Australia why he has not responded to the devaluation of the dollar-it is a good question-one will always get the same answer: High interest rates. They say: `How can we compete with interest rates offered in other parts of the world?' As an example I cite Singapore whose interest rate is today at 6 per cent. In Australia today, adding on the bank charges, for a normal bank overdraft the rate is about 21 per cent.

Let us look at our inflation compared with the rest of the world. The rest of the world is going down to zero; we are going up into double-digit inflation. We face uncertainty about the dollar, which is a reflection of uncertainty about this Government. That is a very important factor. We face high transport costs, particularly at the wharves. I know some efforts are being made to do something about what are called restrictive work practices. However, these efforts have not touched the outlets and inlets of this country. Australia is an island continent which relies on exports and imports; yet the costs of loading goods from a wharf to a ship and transporting those goods overseas, particularly if we use our own vessels, make this prohibitive. The only people I know who are successful in this regard send their goods by air and use non-union labour. The final factor is militant unions, and this comes up in discussions with every group of manufacturers. They will say: `Yes, things have been a bit quiet in recent times because of the state of the economy, but if things improve can we be sure that they will not attack us?'

I refer to comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the visit here by the Japanese trade mission. Of course, he told the mission all the good things that he thought would attract the Japanese to invest in this country. I see that Senator Siddons is in the chamber. He has had experience in Japan and he would recognise the significance of the remarks made by Mr Amaya when he left. They do not inspire a lot of confidence, but I will return to that later. Mr Hawke talked about lifting the burden of government regulation and reforming the tax system to provide incentive to our manufacturing industry. We have the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax; the foreign tax credits have gone and there is no negative gearing. What sort of tax incentive is that? The Government rearranged the tax system and hit the manufacturing sector and other productive sectors. The Prime Minister talked about our industrial relations. This was embarrassing to the Prime Minister because while the mission was here there was a coal strike. The Prime Minister said:
If you exclude coal mining, a sector in which some intractable industrial issues have to be faced, the underlying trend in industrial disputation generally speaking has been downwards since 1983.

This is the man who, in the mid-1970s, went to the Bowen Basin in Queensland and forced the companies, by blatant union muscle, to settle on terms and conditions of employment which flowed on to the rest of Australia and contributed to the demise of our manufacturing industry. Of course, what he did not mention when he told the mission all the good things was our interest rates and our inflation compared with Japan. The members of the mission know that; they are not silly. I was intrigued by the response of Mr Amaya as he left the country. He said that while Australian agriculture had proved very competitive internationally, the same could not be said of manufacturing. He said:
So far it is like a swimmer in the hotel pool . . . he now has to swim in the Pacific Ocean, which is . . . rough.

That is a nice Japanese way to say: `You will not make it unless you do serious things to improve your productivity and competitiveness and unless you get an attitude within the trade union movement that will enable you to be more competitive'. He also said that he respected the manufacturing abilities in the pool-the small domestic Australian market-but he had serious doubts about the ocean. Of course, he has serious doubts about the ocean. Our own people have serious doubts about the ocean. A lot of work has to be done. As I said earlier, noises are being made about correcting some of our restrictive work practices, but the very people who installed them-some of whom have been put in this place by those very militant trade unions-have taken the view that we will do something about it but it will take a little time. We in Australia do not have that time.

I turn to the issue of foreign debt. Not content with throwing taxpayers' money around as drunken sailors would, this Government is intent on mortgaging every Australian to the hilt. The Treasurer of the Labor Government, Mr Keating, is now being referred to as the hundred billion dollar man. This figure of $100 billion is too large for the average Australian to comprehend. What does it mean? It means $6,300 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Every newborn baby gets a little mortgage ticket around its neck to say `I owe you $6,300'. What a great start in life! Such people will not be working for 20 years. If this Government is still in power they will not be working at all. That $100 billion figure means over $14,000 for every taxpayer and over $25,000 for every family in this country. Just to service the debt, just to pay the interest, requires over 40 per cent of our total export income. The Australian Chamber of Commerce said that the problem is greater than the debt headaches of the banana republics of Mexico, Argentina and Nigeria. As an Australian I do not like those comparisons. I am appalled that we should have allowed this country, with all its inherent wealth and all the abilities that we have to offer, to slip to such a stage that we really are not able to pay our way.

High taxes, big government and militant trade unions are the root causes of the problem. The majority of people are fed up. I think this is reflected in the concerns we are seeing around Australia. The sort of thing we see when people become bankrupt, for whatever reason, is that they do chase Messiahs. They will chase any Messiah, even a false Messiah.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who do you have in mind as the false Messiah?

—Let me say, Senator Walsh, that it is not you. This Government, if it is serious, must introduce a mini-Budget. It really has no choice and it must provide lower and flatter rates of income tax so that we can provide more incentive for people and so that there is not a disincentive to work. That is the case in this country today: There is a disincentive to work. We need significant reductions in government expenditure and fiddling around with the edges just will not do. In fact, sometimes I think the Labor Government would be wise to give Senator Walsh his head, because I think he might do something. But he is outmanoeuvred by some weirdos out there who make life difficult. But I think he might succeed. The disincentives to investment must be abolished. We must get rid of disincentives to investment such as interest rates which are too high, capital gains taxes, negative gearing restrictions, foreign tax credits measures and so on. The labour market must be opened up to the competitive world so that disincentives to work and to the creation of jobs are removed forever. The Hawke Labor Government in its economic management of Australia has not been left with a feather to fly with. People are desperate and the desperation is reflected throughout the length and breadth of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this General Business motion, I would point out to the Senate that there is no government anywhere in the world that is tackling inflationary price rises with more vigor, imagination and determination than this Labor Government in Australia. This afternoon we are debating a motion which claims that food prices are rising by some 8.6 per cent a year. It is important to bear in mind that when the Fraser-Howard Government left office at the beginning of 1983 inflation was not 8.6 per cent but 11.5 per cent a year. The Labor Government inherited double digit inflation. When Mr Howard, the current Leader of the Opposition, was Treasurer, after five Budgets he left the Australian people with inflation running at 11.5 per cent. Yet this afternoon Opposition senators have had the gall to move a motion claiming that inflation is running at 8.6 per cent and blaming this Government for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals' stated policy in the 1970s, as I remember well, was `Fight inflation first'. That is the slogan they took with them when they went around the country, and the policy they put to the Australian people. Members of the community were told that they had to tighten our belts and make sacrifices in the name of the policy of fighting inflation first. The Liberals brought out their gurus from various obscure overseas institutes to tell us that we did have to make sacrifices. It was summed up in the statement that there was no such thing as a free lunch, which was one of the major statements in the 1970s in the name of fighting inflation first. That policy was a failure and Mr Howard, as Treasurer, was a failure in fighting inflation. After five Budgets we in Australia were left with double digit inflation-it was running at 11.5 per cent. All the sacrifices were in vain. There were cuts in government spending and government services were reduced in the name of fighting inflation first. it was a complete and utter failure. Therefore, we could not rely on the Liberals, in the unlikely event that they come to occupy the treasury bench, to do anything about inflation. Based on their past record, they are quite hopeless at fighting inflation. Their record is there for all Australians to see. Mr Howard and his Liberal colleagues are going around Australia now claiming that they will reduce inflation from the current 9.8 per cent, but we are entitled to inquire: `Who put it up to 11.5 per cent in 1983?' This Government got inflation and price rises down to 9.8 per cent compared with the 11.5 per cent when Mr Howard was Treasurer.

I am not satisfied with an inflation rate of 9.8 per cent. It is far too high, and the Government believes that. But we have the policies that can reduce the inflation rate. Agreements with the trade union movement through the accord were successful in reducing inflation in the first three years of the Government. The rate came down significantly, but it ran into the difficulties caused by the devaluation of the Australian dollar-and the consequent impact on import prices-which has amounted to some 40 per cent against the American dollar in the past two years. We are a trading nation and that effect is unavoidable. Some 15 to 20 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product, effectively, is in traded items. Therefore, the effect of a devaluation forces up the Australian dollar price of those traded items so that that price effect spreads throughout the economy and must have an effect on the overall measures of inflation, including the consumer price index. A significant element of the CPI is higher import prices. It is ridiculous to blame this Government for the effect of devaluation in forcing up prices as a result of higher import prices.

The period of office of the Liberals was characterised not only by double digit inflation. Mr Howard, as outgoing Treasurer in 1983, also left Australia with double digit unemployment. The jobless rate in that year peaked at a level of 10.4 per cent. That put one person in 10 in the labour force out of work and looking for employment. We are entitled to ask why that was the case and how it happened. The reason was the alarming fall in employment levels in this country during 1982 and at the beginning of 1983. In the last 12 months that Mr Howard, the current Leader of the Opposition, was Treasurer, from March 1982 to March 1983, some 157,000 Australians were thrown on the industrial scrapheap as a result of his policies. That was all in the name of fighting inflation first. The policy of bringing down the inflation rate was the centrepiece of Liberal policy in those years. The Liberal Government tried to moderate price rises in the community by regulating the level of unemployment. It was as simple as that. That Government used the unemployment level in the community as a tool to try to regulate the rate of inflation and of price increases. It failed dismally in achieving that goal.

This motion today claims that there has been a lack of job growth. The motion has been moved by a member of the Liberal Party, a party which presided over the loss of 157,000 jobs in 1982 and 1983 but which now claims that there has been a lack of job growth under the present administration. That is absolute nonsense. It is totally hypocritical for Liberals to come into the Senate today and chastise and berate this Government about alleged job losses when their record in the Fraser-Howard Government was the worst in this country since the Great Depression in the 1930s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at 1972 to 1975.

—That was the case, Senator Archer. Senator Archer continues to show his ignorance of the facts, and I suggest that as a shadow Minister he should be well aware that the unemployment rate in 1982 and 1983 was well above the levels in the mid-1970s. That happened because Mr Howard's policy as Treasurer was to attempt to regulate the inflation rate by regulating unemployment. He depressed the economy to try to reduce the inflation rate, and failed. He left Australia in a situation in which one person in 10 was out of work in 1983. That was his record of achievement after five years as Treasurer of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is an absolute nonsense in claiming a lack of job growth under the present administration. The fact is that in the 1983 election we promised to create 500,000 jobs in three years. I well recall members of the Liberal Party scoffing at that pledge by Mr Hawke in that election. They said that it could not be done; they ridiculed it, and said that it would be impossible for the Labor Government to create 500,000 jobs in its first three years of office. That is what they told the Australian people; and I suppose that that attitude could be explained as being based on the Liberals' record. Their record meant that some 157,000 jobs were lost in their last year of office. The record is that we created 500,000 extra jobs with months to spare-well within the three-year time horizon. Up to and including January of this year, from the National Economic Summit in April 1983, the figure has now reached 727,000, a stupendous record. Yet we have this hopeless, divided Opposition, racked with internal division, coming into the chamber and, in a motion, claiming a lack of job growth. Under the Hawke Government more than 700,000 jobs have been created. Mr Howard, in his last year as Treasurer, destroyed 157,000 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?
—Who did that?

—It was Mr John Howard, who was the Treasurer of Australia from 1978 to 1983 and who brought down five Budgets. He was the Treasurer who left Australia with double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. We inherited an unemployment rate of over 10 per cent. It peaked at 10.4 per cent in 1983 but by January this year it was down to 8.2 per cent. That is a quite significant reduction in the jobless rate in Australia. As a member of the Labor Party, I find an 8.2 per cent unemployment rate unacceptably high, but it is certainly vastly preferable to the 10.4 per cent that resulted from the Fraser-Howard recession of 1982-83.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is a nonsense in other areas. I note that it refers to taxation, claiming that at present taxes are high in Australia and that we in the Labor Party are members of a high taxing Government. I refer to Budget Paper No. 1, the definitive part of the Budget in which the economic and statistical calculations are all set out. It is very interesting to look at the taxation record of the Fraser-Howard Administration as set out in Budget Paper No. 1. Let us look at the role of taxation under that Liberal administration-the administration that said it would cut taxes, reduce the overall burden of taxation in Australia and reduce the load on the backs of Australian taxpayers. When one compares the share of Australia's gross domestic product which went in taxation at the end of Mr Howard's period as Treasurer with the share of gross domestic product going in taxation at the beginning of the period of the Fraser Government, one sees that that share had risen, not fallen. In seven years in office the Liberals did not bring taxation down as they today claim they did and as they say they would in the future. In fact, the share of Australia's gross domestic product going in taxation under the Fraser-Howard Government rose by 1.7 percentage points. At the end of that period of office the share of our national income, our gross domestic product, was more than 1 3/4 per cent higher than it was at the beginning of that Government's period in office.

This Government has introduced a major reform of taxation in Australia. It is the only Government in the post-war period which has shaken up the taxation system. It is an absolute nonsense for the Liberals to claim that the Australian Labor Party is a high tax party. I simply refer to the income tax scales with which we are all familiar, as we are all taxpayers here-or I hope we are. It is interesting that in Mr Howard's last Budget as Treasurer in 1982 the lowest tax rate paid by Australians was 30c in the dollar. That was the lowest marginal tax rate. Under the Labor Government the bottom tax rate is not 30c in the dollar or even 29c in the dollar; it is 24c in the dollar. There is a major reduction in marginal tax rates. Let us look at the tax free threshold, the exemption from taxation for all taxpayers. Under Mr Howard that exemption applied to income up to $4,595; under this Government the threshold will rise to some $5,100. That is a major increase in that indicator of taxation levels.

One of the important characteristics of the tax package was that it led to a much fairer and much more equitable taxation system in Australia. That was what it was all about-getting rid of all the rorts and ramps in the Australian taxation system under Mr Howard and introducing more fairness into the system. One of the matters we debated in the last 18 months was the end of the tax subsidised lunch, the so-called free lunch which was enjoyed by businessmen around Australia at taxpayers' expense. The rest of us paid for it because the expense claims were allowable as a deduction from income. The end of that device is now netting the Government some $300m extra a year-a great improvement in the fairness of the tax system. A much more equitable tax system has resulted from that measure. It is interesting to look at the claims that were made in this place and elsewhere by Liberal and National Party members at the time of the introduction of that tax. They claimed that Labor's crackdown on the tax subsidised lunch would wreak havoc in the Australian economy and destroy the hospitality and restaurant industries. Some amazing claims were made by the Opposition spokespersons in this place and elsewhere about the impact of that measure on industry. Those sorts of claims and their lack of credibility have been totally exposed. They undermine completely the current claims that are being made by Liberal and National Party spokespersons about the Australian economy and taxation.

I wish to refer to some of the claims that were made in this place and elsewhere when this Government courageously cracked down on the tax subsidised lunch and saved Australian taxpayers $300m a year. On 3 December 1985 Senator Messner, the Opposition tax spokesperson, said that 11,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant and hospitality industries because the Labor Government was cracking down on the free lunch. Senator Knowles, who comes from Western Australia, in her speech at that time said that some 5,000 workers in the restaurant industry had already been sacked. That was the claim she made following Labor's crackdown on the lurks and perks of a select group in the community. Senator Boswell, who is a National Party senator from Queensland, said on 4 December 1985:
. . . I believe it will be around February or March-
there he means February or March 1986-
There will be a massive fall in the industry.

That is, in the restaurant and hospitality industries. Senator Boswell was making a categorical claim. He went on to say that some 14,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry. Then we had Senator Short claiming that almost 20,000 persons could be put out of work in the restaurant industry. He is a former officer in the Treasury, the most important financial department in the land. He claimed that almost 20,000 jobs could be lost in the restaurant industry as a result of this Government's far sighted and fair crackdown on the free lunch. Then we had Mr Hodgman, who is a member of the other place, claiming that not 11,000 jobs, not 5,000, not 14,000 and certainly not 20,000, but 80,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry as a result of this Government's reform of the taxation system. Then Senator Jessop, a member of this place, said:
. . . early in 1986 we will see the demise of many restaurants throughout Australia.

That was a very categorical statement by Senator Jessop, who comes from my own State of South Australia. I hope that he read the article in the Adelaide News on New Year's Day this year which carried a big headline `Our restaurant trade thriving'. This article examined in great detail the health of the restaurant industry around Australia and came to the conclusion that, following Labor's crackdown on the free lunch, the restaurant trade was thriving. It quoted Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association, who said:
I don't know of one restaurant in the Melbourne city area that has closed.
Senator Short comes from Victoria and has his office in the metropolitan area of Melbourne. He claimed in his place on 4 December 1985 that almost 20,000 jobs would be lost in that industry.

Members of the Opposition have absolutely no credibility. This afternoon I have exposed all these ridiculous claims about what would happen to this industry. Those claims were made by Liberal and National Party senators about Labor's tax reforms in a key part of the tax system. Those claims have all been exposed as ridiculous and nonsensical. Now those opposite move this motion which claims among other things that there are higher taxes, a lack of job growth in Australia and other items. That is absolute nonsense. I suppose that those are the only things on which those opposite can agree at the moment and that is the reason for moving this motion. The internal divisions and tensions in the coalition are such that the only thing those opposite can agree on at the moment is attacking the Government and making such absolutely nonsensical claims as have been made this afternoon.

Senator Parer is a senator for whom I have some respect. He led this debate this afternoon and talked about Australia's foreign debt. I may be wrong but I listened very carefully-and I read articles on foreign debt very carefully-and I do not think Senator Parer this afternoon referred once to the fact that the great majority of Australia's overseas debt has been incurred by private corporations. The thing that really concerns me about the Opposition at the moment is this misleading rubbish it is pushing, that somehow all of Australia's overseas debt has been incurred by the Federal Government. He did not chastise Sir Roderick Carnegie or other industrialists in Australia. The clear import of the remarks and notes of all the speakers opposite, which are clearly coming from their national secretariat, is that somehow this debt has been incurred by the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that at all.

—I ask the honourable senator to show me some contributions made by honourable senators in his Party which put at the very forefront of this problem the fact that this debt has been incurred by private corporations. A major article in the Sun-Herald of 15 February points out that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd alone, not the Federal Government of Australia-not the Hawke Government-is responsible for 4.8 per cent of Australia's foreign debt. So one-twentieth of Australia's foreign debt has been run up by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the pillar of the Melbourne establishment. It is that company that has run up the debt, not Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

SPEECH.PARA: For Thomas Nationwide Transport, the transport group which is a major shareholder in Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, the foreign debt incurred in 1985-86 rose by 49 per cent. That is the company that is managed by Sir Peter Abeles. News Corporation Ltd, Mr Murdoch's international vehicle, incurred not a 49.1 per cent growth in foreign debt in 1985-86, not a 59 per cent growth, not a 69 per cent growth, but a whopping 122 per cent growth in foreign debt. CRA which used to be known as Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, a major mining group based in Melbourne with whom Sir Roderick Carnegie has been associated for many years-and I heard Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in the chamber this afternoon parrot off some statement made by Sir Roderick last week in which he said he was alarmed about debt, but he did not mention that CRA, his own company, was one of the major players in this drama-in 1985-86 incurred a massive 52 per cent growth in foreign debt. That is what is going on.

These are not borrowings by the Commonwealth of Australia or by the Australian Labor Party but borrowings by people who are held up in the community as leaders and far-sighted entrepreneurs carving out the world for free enterprise. These are the fellows who are putting Australia into hock. Elders IXL Ltd, the vehicle of Mr John Elliott, the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party, has incurred a massive increase in foreign debt in the last year. Mr Alan Bond's Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd did not increase its foreign debt by the 49 per cent the TNT group increased it by, or the 122 per cent that News Corporation increased it by; he trebled it in one year. We are getting blamed by the imbeciles on the other side, the Opposition, for this debt which was incurred by these people who support the Opposition. This massive increase in debt is being incurred by such people.

This motion is incredibly backward-looking in one particular area. I refer to point (g) on page 2 of the motion which calls for the development of new import replacement industries. One of the problems that Australia has at the moment is that we have far too many import replacement industries. That is one of the big legacies that was left to the current Federal Government and State governments to deal with-that our industrial structure is far too heavily dependent on import replacing activities. That is what happened in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s under Liberal Premiers like Bolte and Playford who went around the world every year looking for more import replacing industries to attract to Australia. They scrambled overseas to get those industries to come to this country. Now we are paying the legacy of having those types of industries. We have too many factories making rubber tyres and too many car plants. We could name other industries where there has been a proliferation in the numbers of plants, with high costs of production and short production runs so that they do not get economies of scale and heavily tariff dependent.

One has only to look at the industrial structure of Victoria which was bequeathed to the people of Victoria by Mr Bolte's Government. It has the most tariff dependent industrial structure in Australia. One of the reasons for that is the mad scramble that used to go on in the 1950s and 1960s with the Liberal State Premiers going around the world attracting very inefficient plants to Australia. We have a car industry which is incredibly fragmented as a result of having too many producers and plants. The effect is small production runs and high costs of production.

This afternoon I noticed that after all the palaver in this motion it goes on to call for the abolition of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the taxation on lump sum superannuation. But I cannot see any reference there to the end of the free lunch. After the way Liberal and National Party members and senators in 1985 went out on a limb saying that they would overturn Labor's crackdown on the free lunch-when we courageously went about ripping that rort out of the tax system and putting more fairness into it by ending the tax subsidised lunch and the Liberals saying that they would overturn Labor's initiative in that area-I would have thought that we would find a commitment in this motion to restore the tax-subsidised lunch. But I fail to see it. I see a commitment to do other things but it seems that the Opposition, as in so many areas at the moment, is hopelessly divided. It does not know where it is going and its members are unable to agree on a taxation policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a very sad tale from both sides-of failure by Liberal governments, which Senator Maguire has put out, and failure by Labor governments, which Senator Parer has put out. I believe the commencing statement by Senator Maguire that Labor had approached the problem of the economy with imagination can be interpreted only in the way that it imagines that it is doing a good job in this area. None of the statistics which have been put forward in relation to this motion and which are supported by the actual figures, by what is happening in the community, are a compliment to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Maguire spent considerable time making excuses, basically comparing the performance of the Labor Government with the pathetic performance of the previous Liberal Government. I believe that is not good enough for the people of Australia. People who are excellent at making excuses are seldom good at anything else. That is the problem with this Government. It is very sad when members of a government come to this chamber and act like an opposition and spend most of their time justifying their government by attacking the government before it. This Government has been in sufficiently long to be able to be responsible for the state which we are in. I believe it cannot hide behind the mess that the previous Government left it, although I do agree that it left the country in a mess. It is because of this that the Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment to the motion which we have before us today. It is because we believe that neither the Labor Party nor the coalition has any solutions. We agree with their diagnosis of the problem, and we have heard a lot about that diagnosis-I will come back to some of those points-but we have not had solutions. I certainly do not believe that the solutions that are proposed at the end of the motion that we have before us today from the Opposition are any type of solution to the economic morass that we are in. It mentions lower and flatter rates of income tax. We agree that there should be significant reductions in government expenditure. We cannot see how the abolition of the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and lump sum superannuation tax would have very much effect on all the other things in the motion, such as the massive foreign debt and the current real problems of trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Modified snake oil, watered down snake oil-that's all it is.
—It is because of this that the Democrats are suggesting specific solutions to the problem. It might do Senator Walsh some good to listen to some of these solutions. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after ``include'', insert: ``lower rates of income tax for Australians, and measures to encourage export-directed industries with a high value-added; control flows of speculative capital in and out of the country, including introduction of a tax on moneys leaving the country implement a significant and cost-effective reduction in government expenditure; close off the taxation rorts of transfer pricing and negative gearing on interest paid on money borrowed for company takeovers; and calls on all parties and all Australians to unite in an effort to overcome the current economic crisis facing Australia.''

TALK.START.PARA: —You always want to spend more money.

—We are moving to encourage export directed industry with high value added. We will spend money to earn money. That is what business is about. That is what people on the honourable senator's side of the House are supposed to understand.
—How are you going to do that?

—We will tell the honourable senator about that a bit later. We will also try to protect the Australian economy from the types of distortions about which Senator Maguire has told us-the distortions which Mr Murdoch, Elders-IXL, Mr Bond and such people and companies have introduced into our economy by borrowing so much money abroad and now being subsidised--
—How have they blown out the deficit?

—They have borrowed abroad and they are being subsidised, Senator Walsh, by the taxpayers of Australia, and with your collusion. That is exactly what is happening. The major problem that we have is that the Government does not have the guts to act against those people. Its members stand up here and say `It's their fault, it's their fault', and continue to allow them a complete free-for-all. For a Labor government to allow that free-for-all does not accord with the policy principles which are passed from time to time at its policy conferences.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area at which we are looking is that of controlling the flow of speculative capital into and out of the country. I believe we could make it very uncomfortable for those people who are misusing the foreign exchange fluctuations in Australia and distorting our economy by having a tax on moneys leaving the country. It would not have to be a very large tax. If, every time people have large numbers of dollars flowing out of the country, we took some percentage of that money and put it into the general coffers of the government we would be able to cut taxes for ordinary Australians-the type of thing that most of us would want.

I would expect a Labor government with the bureaucratic background that socialism always brings with it not to want to cut government expenditure; it would want the public sector to grow. But we have to cut down on the ineffective parts of the public sector. We have to make cost-effective reductions in the public sector. We also want to close off the taxation rorts-not the silly little taxation rorts of people from time to time sneaking a free lunch, but the enormous, horrific taxation rorts of transfer pricing and negative gearing on interest paid on moneys borrowed for company takeovers-when the people of Australia are subsidising large corporations, in many cases large overseas corporations, for their particular entrepreneurial and speculative activities. I believe it is important that the Government should protect the people of Australia against this type of manipulation.

In the Democrats' amendment, we call upon all parties and all Australians to unite in an effort to overcome the current economic crisis facing Australia, instead of fighting. We have this Parliament divided in itself, with members fighting one another, calling one another names, with no solutions. Here the Democrats are offering some solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?

—That is what I am about to point out. The Government has under its control five factors with which it can control the problem if it has a determination to act. I believe it has to act immediately for the benefit of the Australian economy and for ordinary Australians. These particular factors are: The interest rates; the money supply; the taxation levels; direct and indirect incentives to business through bounties, grants, training and education; and the cutting of government expenditure on useless bureaucratic activities.
—On what?
—I am coming to that, Senator Parer. I am coming to where we can have some cuts. We have so many quangos around that are doing very little that we really need to look at them in some areas.
—We know all that. Just tell us which.

—I will tell you some. The Opposition has a waste watch committee. Single-handedly sometimes I have to sit in on the Estimates committees to find out some of this waste, and the Opposition has to its credit taken up some of it. I believe we have to continue this type of pursuit of waste in the Public Service. The interest rates in Australia are well above those in other industrialised countries. The Government will not force them down because it feels this would discourage foreign investment. It may also be that interest rates are kept high to please the large commercial investors. When a corporate debtor in the system controls 75 per cent of the daily print media in the nation-that is just one that has been mentioned to us-we have a potential force in politics for keeping inflation up because debtors benefit, rather than lose, from inflation. Foreign investment in Australia, as we have seen recently in the famous takeover battles, is doing nothing for Australia-nothing at all. Currently that sector of the private sector is being subsidised by the taxpayer because of the slackness of the Government that is sitting currently on the treasury bench. Australia is paying out an amount equal to 28 per cent of its current monthly exports just to cover its debt. This is a higher percentage than Chile with 23 per cent; the Philippines with 21 per cent; Indonesia with 21 per cent; Mexico with 18 per cent; Brazil with 14 per cent; and Argentina with 13 per cent. We are not in a very reasonable state.
—The United States?

—The United States is exploiting the system currently as well. Inflation is being kept high by high interest rates and also by rises in the price of manufactured goods, increases in medical fund contributions and other charges for services. On the whole, it is also being kept high by various types of taxes-consumption taxes like the wholesale sales tax and the petroleum excise. The report of the Bureau of Industry Economics on `Manufactured Exports and the 1985 Devaluation', released in October 1986 pointed out that the manufacturing sector has run down its productive capacity, in the interests of rationalisation, to such low levels that it is now unable and unwilling to expand for import replacement, let alone for increased exports. Australia is now not a very comfortable place to be if one is a manufacturer. The Government can affect interest rates through the bond rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The money supply is another area which is related to that. Disposable income is being kept low by inflation, high interest rates and high unemployment. Consumer prices rose 2.6 per cent in the September quarter to reach a level of 8.9 per cent above the level a year ago. For example, fuel costs rose 6.3 per cent; lamb and mutton costs rose 11.8 per cent; and the cost of fresh fruit and vegetables rose 13.2 per cent. Wages are further depressed by the perception that they are a primary inflationary factor in the economy. This is the real problem.

This Government, because it has a direct tap into the unions, is actually acting against the interests of the people whom it purports to represent-that is, the ordinary working man in Australia. The Government is actually depressing the wages with respect to other factors in the economy. Indeed, it is a common misconception that wages are an independent variable and that prices follow wages. One has a real problem if wage increases exceed productivity increases because the relative value of the goods in the monetary system goes down. Monetary and fiscal measures, in conjunction with labour cost movements, should be able to control prices. The Government has been unwilling-maybe unable-to carry this out. I believe that this is an indictment of the Government's economic management. In fact, in Australia, wage price rises usually lag well behind price increases and are not an independent variable. But limited income is also named as a causative factor in the sluggish demand for consumer goods. Inflation was running at 8 to 9 per cent in the six months to September 1986. Real average earnings and household disposable income fell. Household consumption expenditure increased a little through a decline in the household savings ratio; that is, people had to take out of their own savings to live. That is what is happening to Australians-they are having to put their money into their pockets to finance this Government's high tastes and the high tastes of those industrialists who are milking the system through using negative gearing in their takeover bids and by overheating the stock market.

With the slow growth of disposable incomes, there seems little hope for any real growth in private sector consumer spending for the rest of this financial year. So there is little hope on the horizon. Wage rises, to the recently agreed first tier increase of $10, which is about 2 per cent of average weekly earnings, plus 3 per cent on an industrial basis, means that there will be a total wage increase of 5 per cent. This amounts to a wage erosion of 4 per cent when compared with an inflation rate of 9 per cent per annum. In fact, what is happening is exactly what the Opposition is suggesting should happen. But, really, this will not be very good for the ordinary workers in Australia who have lost 4 per cent of their real purchasing power.

Tight money means continued slow domestic demand and a very slow domestic outlook. It also means that there is an inability for industry to invest in export capacity or even to go into import substitution. Tight money is putting an enormous strain on the building industry. It is keeping interest rates and unemployment up and employment down.

Another contributory factor in our current economic system is the level of taxation. Taxation on production is high but there is little taxation on consumption. I believe that somehow we have to change that balance. But we have to change it in a way that is fair for the poorer people in our community. We cannot end up with a broad-scale consumption tax as has been proposed in one of the leaked Opposition tax packages. If this were to happen we would disadvantage the poorer and medium income earners in our community who are the backbone of the Australian economy. It is extremely important that we should give these people incentive and that we should not put taxes on the necessities of life. The Democrats will make certain that no such iniquitous taxes will be allowed to develop. However, that does not mean that we should not be decreasing or lowering income tax and removing completely payroll tax, both of which are directly against the interests of improving production in Australia.

We must also try to develop some entrepreneurial skills in our businesses. We need to put money into direct and indirect help or subsidies to industries. We need to improve our product research and the quality of our products. We need to develop products which are aimed at specific export markets, particularly ones that we can transport exports to rather easily. The confidence in the manufacturing sector depends on low interest rates and on a certain and constant economic outlook. Indeed, this confidence can be built up by the Government in training people to take risks and to understand the process of being entrepreneurial, allowing business to go out to try to sell overseas and giving it the advantage of as much Government backup as possible. I am very pleased that Austrade has been set up and that that body provides some new facilities in this area. But we need to be much more dynamic in terms of developing our own shipping and in terms of developing our own insurance or reinsurance industry which a Bill of mine is designed to handle.

We must be much more dynamic in terms of recognising products and infant industries on which we can spend money, in which the Government can be an investor or a supportive force. We need to do this if we are actually to have some products to export in the next decade. If we just go for the quick buck now we will go down the tube. What we are suffering from now is the fact that people went for the quick buck during the 1960s and the 1970s instead of investing in the future. We are also suffering from the branch office syndrome. We believe that everything that is overseas and in head office is so much better and we cringe about something that is developed in Australia. We have to overcome this. That is part of the training and the leadership that have to be given by this Government, and also by this Opposition. Instead of talking the economy down we should be talking it up. We are all in this together. This is a real problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keating has been trying that for years.

—Why does the honourable senator not help? We should help govern the country instead of just knocking people. We have to stop the wastage that is occurring. The Australian Democrats are the only party that is against the enormous expenditure and extravagance on the new Parliament House. We have been against the growing bureaucracy in a number of areas.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the Opposition's view that the fringe benefits tax and the complex tax laws have led to enormous numbers of people in the Public Service and an enormous growth in quangos. Each of these needs to be investigated and its cost effectiveness determined. The Government can take action in all these ways: We can educate people to have a `volunteer mindset' and to actually do more than just go to a 9 to 5 job, but they will not do this unless the Government turns this into something which is thought to be an Australian way of doing things.

It is extremely important that we should be boosting the money supply sufficiently to be able to allow new value added industries into the area and to improve our technology base. This means that we will have to distort in some way the distribution of money to be able to advantage those industries which can earn us foreign exchange and use our labour force. We have in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, in the universities and in other organisations really brilliant people who have a lot of ideas. However, what happens when they develop these ideas? The wool spinning technology and Interscan, which were both potential earners of hundreds of millions of dollars, were lost overseas because the Government did not purchase the Australian products. I believe that the Government's attitude to purchasing goes right through to the public servants. The public servants cannot be blamed for not buying Australian if the Government is doing no more than the type of cosmetic exercise it is doing now with its Buy Australian campaign. It has to get into this area and give us the lead. That is what we are here for.

We have plants that are empty, such as the General Motors-Holden's Ltd plant at Woodville in my State of South Australia. These plants could be used. There are people who are willing to use them and who have ideas as to how to use them. But when they come forward they are asked by bankers and by the Government: `What asset backing do you have?' The only way a person can get into a high-tech industry now is by hocking his house, by hocking his car and by leaving himself completely open to the vagaries of the financial system. If we could give our technologists the type of support that they need they would repay us a thousandfold.
I believe it is also important that we should lower the taxes. We should introduce new types of taxes which are fairer than the current ones and which will not support--

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort are they?

—I am just going to tell the honourable senator about some of them. Let us just take an example. If we had a corporate turnover tax we could collect sufficient revenue to replace the current income tax system. A tax of just 1.5 per cent to 2 per cent of corporate gross turnover would allow us to replace the total income tax area for private citizens. I am not saying that this would do a lot for business. What we have to do in order to make such a tax sensible within our community is to exempt labour from this tax and to exempt materials on which the tax has already been paid. That is fairly easy to do with normal accounting systems. It would give us a non-progressive tax which we call a materials added tax and which would have the advantage of giving an incentive to manufacturing industry--
—What if you aren't making any profit?

—If a person is not making any profit that person should not be in that type of business. We are not trying to give a tax on profit. A person should organise his business and take the tax into account at that stage. I believe that it is extremely important to have such a tax in conjunction with income tax because that will cut out the cash economy. All businesses would declare every skerrick of labour which they employed, so there would be no free labour market to feed the cash economy. It would also mean that all accounts would be available on all types of goods. That would be a necessity. It would have a devastating effect on organised crime. It would cut it down because those records would be available to government. The tax would be simple to administer, not like the vast complexity of the current income tax and sales tax provisions which we now have.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last couple of minutes available to me I would like to deal with foreign debt. We are now facing a foreign debt of $100 billion. Last month Australia had to borrow a further $2,687m to cover the outflow of the Australian dollar. A large part of this outflow comes from the seeking of speculative gains through the devaluation of the dollar. In terms of debt repayment, as a percentage of current monthly export income Australia's debt is way above that of a large number of comparable countries that we would consider to be Third World countries. If we had a tax on moneys leaving the country-even a small percentage-this would act as a brake on speculative outflows of money from Australia and it would also tax net imports into Australia while not penalising the importation of manufactured components for re-export. Essentially, we would have a free trade area in terms of components coming in and going out, but we would tax the net flows of money across the border. The private sector debt has resulted, in a large part, from the increased takeover activity and we need to do something in the taxation system to stop the rorts associated with negative gearing and transfer pricing.

In terms of reduced government expenditure, which I have very little time to discuss, we have to be ever vigilant and we have to look at the net cost benefits of departments. For example, the Department of Communications is a net earner of money for the Government because it is selling our airwaves to people. We should note that fact and not cut its funds but we should ask for a better performance. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Parer, who has moved the motion before us. I think it is worth saying at the outset that there does not seem to be a general awareness or an acceptance in this chamber of the proposition that the business of government is about taking tough decisions. It certainly seems to be becoming increasingly accepted by people such as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, who in this chamber not so long ago accepted the proposition put by Sir Roderick Carnegie that there are many tough years ahead. If we accept the Treasurer's prognostications, it will probably be another 10 years. The question is whether that is really a function of government or whether it is due to matters beyond the Government's control, bearing in mind that it has now been in office for almost four years. I do not want to go back over the past because I do not think it is relevant to the present. Certainly, one can look at a range of Government actions in recent times to see whether there has been the capacity for the Government to take tougher action to correct what I think are now generally recognised as very serious economic difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably a useful starting point is the area of wages policy because that is the area in which the Government has trumpeted great success, the area in which it has an accord based on an arrangement with the trade union movement. The renegotiated mark 3 version is no more than a pea and thimble trick. It has now resulted in a two-tier wage system which has led the Australian Council of Trade Unions to seek a $20 a week wage increase plus a second tier wage increase of at least 4 per cent at the national wage case. If anything were calculated to cause a run on the Australian dollar it is the prospect of that sort of claim succeeding. One would hope that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will have the good sense not to capitulate to the ACTU in the way the Government has clearly encouraged the unions to press for the claim.

Perhaps one of the most depressing quotations that I have seen in a long while is one that was handed to me not so long ago. It gives an example of why the trade union movement is prepared to embark on wholly irresponsible claims and somehow to pretend that others should be sharing the burden. There is still no shortage of trade union leaders who will say that somehow they should not be copping all the blame and that others should wear it. Honourable senators should listen to this: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when ACTU Federal President and the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, stated in August 1974:

We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it's quite likely to reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters. But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

That is a tragic indictment. Unless the Prime Minister has completely transformed his thinking, he continues to believe that inanity. If he has done so, then by his example he has encourage others to behave in a totally irresponsible manner. The end result in terms of wages policy is that there is no prospect of Australia achieving a sensible reduction in wages to make us more competitive. As a result we have a 9.8 per cent inflation rate which, as we know, is a multiple of that of our trading partners. I think Japan and West Germany now have negative inflation rates. In the United Kingdom and the United States of America inflation is very close to zero. Yet we have a rate that shows no signs of going in the required direction. That is one of the first and most obvious areas of Government neglect and default.

Probably enough has been said about the level of foreign debt, but it is quite clear that again it has not come about accidentally. It is not due to factors beyond our control except to the extent that the terms of trade have gone against us and our export prices have been pushed down fairly dramatically as a result of an oversupply in primary commodities. But again that is a question of the Government not having taken action to provide incentives to manufacturing to export more. That is tied in with wages policy and tied in generally with the economic climate. No one would suggest that somehow we could have ridden through the current crisis given the accumulation of over-protection and the way in which the economy has been allowed to ossify. Certainly, in the last four years there has been precious little attempt to come to grips with the real difficulties the country faces.

It should be no surprise to us that we face record levels of foreign debt. If we look around the world to our major trading partner, it is quite obvious that it will be faced with the same sorts of problems. There have even been estimates that it could reach a foreign debt level of $800 billion by the turn of this decade. If that were so, it would probably be in the top 10 Third World nations in terms of indebtedness. If one has debt service ratios such as that one is in big trouble. I do not know whether it is about to lose its AAA rating but it certainly suggests that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Somebody must have a lot of capital out.
—It is probably spending beyond its means. We know that it is in certain areas such as defence, but the end result is that Germany and Japan have massive trade surpluses.
—The United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, West Germany.

—The United States is one of the largest debtor nations in the world at present so it does not have the capital surplus to redistribute. The problem is that if it does the right thing and gets its house in order it will reduce world demand for its imports. Again, that would have an impact on us.
—Nobody tells us whom they owe it to.
—Whom they owe it to?
—Who owns the capital and lends it out?

—I suppose it is a whole set of creditors around the world. But what has happened in many ways is that with its level of interest rates it was able to attract capital into that country long after it should have flown elsewhere. We will have the same problem here. I understand why we have record rates of interest across the board extending into all areas. I think Senator Button cited not so long ago the bank home mortgage rate of 15.5 per cent, which is a fixed figure. It would probably be higher if it were allowed to float. Bank overdraft rates for amounts under $100,000 range from 17.5 per cent to 20.5 per cent and building society mortgage rates stand at 15.63 per cent. They are all at horrific levels. The reason for that is that the Reserve Bank of Australia has been forced to set rates sufficiently high to attract overseas investment. Unfortunately, most of it is highly speculative; a lot of it is Japanese capital that went back home very smartly in January, causing a run on the dollar and requiring the Reserve Bank to step in and prop it up in a massive way. That action was probably justifiable, but obviously there is no prospect of the Reserve Bank's being able to continue it indefinitely. If we have the traditional national average of about three months imports in our foreign exchange reserve there is not much we can do to underpin the value of that dollar. The Reserve Bank cannot get into the business of targeting the exchange rate, and nor should it. Therefore it is a matter of time before either the dollar falls significantly once again or interest rates go even higher, and I do not imagine that that is likely to happen in an election year. As a result we are looking down the barrel.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other areas in which the Government can be held responsible for not having taken the tough action that is required. A lot has been said in recent days about cutting government expenditure. I do not think any serious commentator would pretend that that is not necessary. The thesis of the Business Council of Australia in its submission yesterday was that the Treasurer underestimates the climate for change. I think that is absolutely right. Everyone in this country understands the magnitude of the problem, and people would be much more willing to accept the sorts of cuts that even a few years ago might have provoked howls of outrage and caused governments to be accused of being callous.

A range of options is open to any government that wants to act sensibly and present a May expenditure statement to introduce those cuts. Certainly, in the area of education, I do not quarrel with an administration charge of $250. We could probably go a lot further. We need to make allowances for those who genuinely cannot afford to pay, but it has been proven beyond doubt to be a fallacy that by providing free tertiary education we somehow make it harder for those on lower income levels. The fact is that it has been business as usual except that the taxpayer has been picking up a mammoth bill. I would not have too many difficulties with a proposition that allowed people to borrow in the course of their studies and to repay that money if and when they got into a position in which they could afford to do so. It seems to me that that would not discourage those who are seriously interested in obtaining tertiary qualifications, and it would put the burden where it ought to be. It is a system that applies in places such as West Germany with a minimum of fuss. It is in many ways common sense, but it has not come about because governments have been too frightened to follow it down the track. The proposition of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, of $1,000 per student, in the current climate I would have thought, is well worth another look. But I cannot see this Government doing it; nor can I see it biting the bullet in areas such as health, in which the Centre of Policy Studies suggested there might even be savings of up to $10 billion.

Instead of taking the responsible course and looking seriously at fair work proposals, we will have a community volunteer program, which will probably not do much more than its predecessors. The community employment program has probably resulted in something in excess of $1 billion being spent on make-work programs. In the current climate, I think people would be prepared to accept that there must be a quid pro quo for government payouts and government transfer payments of that order. I think the Government can be held responsible for not cutting back on the size of the public sector.

If we look at the public sector borrowing requirement, the latest figures suggest that if the Government manages to achieve its $3.5 billion deficit, the public sector borrowing requirement will fall marginally to about 4.6 per cent of gross domestic product, as against the 5 per cent figure for the preceding year. The probabilities are that the deficit target will be exceeded and, as a result, there will be little or no reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement. If that is so, one must ask whether there are options open, and that is why the Treasurer has been belting the States around the head in recent days, and justifiably so, I might add. He could in particular single out Queensland as a State that has been squirrelling away much more than it has needed. Again, it has been words rather than action.

The submission of the Business Council of Australia makes it very clear that not only is the climate right, but it would be irresponsible of the Treasurer not to cut back the amount of funds available to the States at the next Premiers Conference. A one per cent cut would involve a reduction in the State authorities' global limit from $6.3 billion in this financial year to about $4 billion next year. Those are very big amounts. The Business Council says that the forward estimate of 3.5 per cent growth is overly optimistic. If one takes a more realistic growth rate of 2.2 per cent, the deficit will be $5.2 billion instead of the currently projected $4.5 billion and the quaint Budget figure of $3.5 billion. There is a dramatic need to reduce the level of current Commonwealth government outlays. If one accepts that the States' deficits will rise in aggregate terms by about $2 billion in 1986-87, that will, in any event, substantially offset any reduction in the Commonwealth deficit. So there is a very urgent need to achieve at least a one per cent cut in that borrowing requirement. The States offer a target in the sense that they are an integral part of the economy and should bear their fair share of the burden.

A number of economic indicators are referred to in the motion that almost speak for themselves. They are a litany of tragedy as far as the economy is concerned. The fact that we have the highest interest rates regime in the Western world says it all. It is the reason why we have been able to live on borrowed time for as long as we have. It does horrific things for savings ratios and investment levels. Those who pretend that somehow companies should be spending more in the current uncertain times really are ignoring reality. They will certainly not be interested in embarking on any more perilous ventures at the moment, when they are fighting for survival.

I say in passing that I was intrigued to hear Senator Maguire trot out the by now trite line about private sector overseas borrowing being a matter for criticism, and in some way excusing the Government's current economic policy. Maybe the people he talks to think that in the past it was all the fault of the public sector but if one analyses the figures I think the ratio is something like 60-40 in favour of private borrowings. But that does not excuse the Government. The reason why those sorts of moneys are borrowed overseas is simply interest rate differentials. A company would be crazy to borrow funds in this country at the rate of 20 per cent when it can borrow funds overseas at the rate of 6 per cent or 7 per cent. Companies will continue to do that. They would be acting irresponsibly, not in the interests of their shareholders, and with a very misguided sense of patriotic duty if they sought somehow to continue to borrow in this country. Those who pretend that one can somehow impose limits on the extent of overseas borrowings-in the way in which King Canute from the Australian Democrats suggested it could be done, by closing off foreign takeover borrowings-are ignoring the realities of life.

Money is a very fungible commodity. It is not a very difficult task for a company simply to readjust its balance sheet so that it is borrowing overseas for a whole range of other activities, and it then finds magically that it has enough money in the domestic kitty to enable it to embark on a takeover proposition. It is simply a matter of switching funds around. There is very little that governments can do to stop it, other than putting the whole corporate sector into a straitjacket. I am sure this Government recognises that, and that is why the Treasurer, to his credit, resisted those sorts of suggestions from the New South Wales branch of his own Party, and Mr MacBean in particular. It is another nonsense. It shows a lamentable misunderstanding of the way in which the economy works.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a form of xenophobia.

—Yes, I think that is right. It is a matter of just identifying multinationals and all of those others in the demonology as the reasons for the problem, rather than accepting responsibility for it. The end result is that one can certainly say that that sort of borrowing will continue; that companies will continue to locate overseas. Pacific Dunlop's recent record profit level was in large part due to its decision to go off-shore. I am sure we will see more of that. I am not critical of any company that finds itself in that position. If Elders IXL Ltd embarks on a takeover for the Guinness company and succeeds, that will simply be in part because it has outgrown the size of the Australian market and because there are precious few investment opportunities left in this country. I think we should welcome companies of our own making that aspire to be genuine multinationals. The world economy is shrinking and there is no reason why they should not be doing that.
